docs.text: Pyloric Stenosis This is one of the most dramatic causes of vomiting in infancy. Typically, the onset is sudden, commencing between the second and sixth week of life. Males are affected five times more often than females and there is a definite familial incidence. Before the onset of vomiting, these infants feed well and are thriving. The vomiting is forceful and rapidly becomes projectile. The infant loses weight and becomes dehydrated. Despite vomiting, these infants remain hungry and are keen to feed even immediately after vomiting. The vomitus is not bile-stained but may contain altered blood. The diagnosis is made clinically by feeling the thickened pylorus (‘pyloric tumour’) in the midline in the epigastrium between the rectus abdominis muscles or in the angle between the right rectus and the liver edge. The pyloric tumour is palpable as a hard mobile mass about the size of a small pebble or olive. Peristaltic waves passing from the left costal margin to the right hypochondrium (‘golfball waves’) may be visible long after the last feed. Palpation of the tumour is sufficient to establish the diagnosis. Pyloric stenosis can also be shown on ultrasonography (which reveals a thickened pylorus) and barium meal (which shows delayed gastric emptying and a narrow pyloric canal). These infants develop a hypokalaemic, hypochloraemic metabolic alkalosis which, together with dehydration, must be corrected before surgery. Pyloromyotomy is curative Most common cause of surgical vomiting 1 in 450 20% family history Onset: 2-7/52 more common in boys (4:1), particularly first-borns. Signs: projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeds, ↑ frequency and severity  marked dehydration (↓skin turgor= wrinkly skin ). Hypochloremic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis from vomiting acid stomach contents. Gastric peristalsis (VGP): “wave moving from left to right across the abdomen” after feed. The palpable “olive” in RUQ US: sonographic criteria: pyloric muscle wall thickness > 3 mm, pyloric canal length 14– 20 mm, pylorus diameter > 12 mm definite Rx pyloromyotomy - muscle, not mucosa, is cut .

docs.text: Short bowel syndrome SHORT BOWEL SYNDROME » General Considerations Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is defined as a condition resulting from reduced intestinal absorptive surface that leads to alteration in intestinal function that compromises normal growth, fluid/electrolyte balance, or hydration status. The vast majority of pediatric patients with SBS have undergone neonatal surgical resection of intestine. The most common etiologies in children are necrotizing enterocolitis (45%); intestinal atresias (23%); gastroschisis Hay_Ch21_p0626-0668.indd 638 20/03/18 12:07 PM GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT 639 (15%); volvulus (15%); and, less commonly, congenital short bowel, long-segment Hirschsprung disease, and ischemic bowel. In many instances, infants with SBS require PN in order to provide adequate caloric, fluid, and electrolyte delivery in the setting of insufficient intestinal absorptive function. The requirement of supplemental PN for more than 2–3 months in the setting of SBS or any other underlying disorder qualifies the diagnosis of intestinal failure (IF). The goal in management of the patient with SBS is to promote growth and adaptation of the intestine such that adequate nutrition can be delivered and absorbed enterally. Many factors, including patient’s gestational age, postsurgical anatomy (including residual small bowel length and presence of ileocecal valve and/or colon), presence of small bowel bacterial overgrowth, and underlying surgical disease, influence the process and likelihood of bowel adaptation and achievement of enteral autonomy. No specific anatomic bowel length measurements offer 100% certainty in predicting clinical outcomes in SBS. » Symptoms & Signs Typical symptoms for the patient with SBS are related to their underlying malabsorptive state, including diarrhea, dehydration, electrolyte or micronutrient deficiency states, and growth failure. Patients with SBS are also at risk for small bowel obstruction, bowel dilation and dysmotility (with secondary small bowel bacterial overgrowth), hepatobiliary disorders including cholelithiasis, nephrolithiasis due to calcium oxalate stones, oral feeding challenges, and GI mucosal inflammatory problems including noninfectious colitis and anastomotic ulcerations. For patients with IF, complications related to underlying PN therapy are common and can be life threatening. PN-associated liver disease (PNALD) is a progressive cholestatic liver injury that occurs in pediatric patients on PN and may progress to end-stage liver disease in 10% of affected patients. Recurrent catheterrelated bloodstream infections are relatively common in pediatric patients with SBS and IF. Other complicationrelated central venous catheters including occlusions may require intervention. » Treatment & Prognosis Goal in management of SBS is to promote growth and adaptation while minimizing and/or treating complications of the underlying intestinal disorder or PN therapy. Intestinal rehabilitation for the child with SBS and IF refers to the multidisciplinary team approach to individual patient care, involving gastroenterology, nutrition, and surgery, and has been shown to improve outcomes. Enteral nutrition should be catered to favor absorption, commonly requiring continuous delivery of an elemental formula through a gastrostomy tube. Commonly prescribed pharmacologic adjuncts include acid suppressive therapy, antimotility and antidiarrheal agents, and antibiotics for the treatment of small bowel bacterial overgrowth. Emerging therapies targeted to promote bowel adaptation include glucagon-like peptide 2 analogues, which show promise in potentially increasing absorption and bowel adaptation in ongoing trials. Management for the patient with SBS and IF should include strategies to manage or prevent complications related to PN therapy, including infection and liver disease. Antimicrobial lock solutions distilled into central venous catheters using either ethanol or antibiotics may have a role in reducing infection rates. Compelling evidence over the past several years suggests that modification of parenteral lipid solution, either through reduction in dose of soy-based intralipid or replacement with a third-generation lipid solution (Omegaven or SMOF lipid), improves outcomes associated with PNALD in pediatric patients. Autologous bowel reconstructive surgery (bowel lengthening) should be considered in a patient who is failing to advance enterally and has anatomy amendable to surgical intervention, typically with regards to adequate bowel dilation. Both the serial transverse enteroplasty (STEP) procedure and longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring (Bianchi) procedure have been successful in allowing weaning from TPN in up to 50% of patients in reported series. In recent years, the STEP procedure has gained favor as being potentially less technically demanding and repeatable, if the bowel dilates sufficiently after the initial procedure. docs.text: SHORT BOWEL SYNDROME » General Considerations Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is defined as a condition resulting from reduced intestinal absorptive surface that leads to alteration in intestinal function that compromises normal growth, fluid/electrolyte balance, or hydration status. The vast majority of pediatric patients with SBS have undergone neonatal surgical resection of intestine. The most common etiologies in children are necrotizing enterocolitis (45%); intestinal atresias (23%); gastroschisis Hay_Ch21_p0626-0668.indd 638 20/03/18 12:07 PM GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT 639 (15%); volvulus (15%); and, less commonly, congenital short bowel, long-segment Hirschsprung disease, and ischemic bowel. In many instances, infants with SBS require PN in order to provide adequate caloric, fluid, and electrolyte delivery in the setting of insufficient intestinal absorptive function. The requirement of supplemental PN for more than 2–3 months in the setting of SBS or any other underlying disorder qualifies the diagnosis of intestinal failure (IF). The goal in management of the patient with SBS is to promote growth and adaptation of the intestine such that adequate nutrition can be delivered and absorbed enterally. Many factors, including patient’s gestational age, postsurgical anatomy (including residual small bowel length and presence of ileocecal valve and/or colon), presence of small bowel bacterial overgrowth, and underlying surgical disease, influence the process and likelihood of bowel adaptation and achievement of enteral autonomy. No specific anatomic bowel length measurements offer 100% certainty in predicting clinical outcomes in SBS. » Symptoms & Signs Typical symptoms for the patient with SBS are related to their underlying malabsorptive state, including diarrhea, dehydration, electrolyte or micronutrient deficiency states, and growth failure. Patients with SBS are also at risk for small bowel obstruction, bowel dilation and dysmotility (with secondary small bowel bacterial overgrowth), hepatobiliary disorders including cholelithiasis, nephrolithiasis due to calcium oxalate stones, oral feeding challenges, and GI mucosal inflammatory problems including noninfectious colitis and anastomotic ulcerations. For patients with IF, complications related to underlying PN therapy are common and can be life threatening. PN-associated liver disease (PNALD) is a progressive cholestatic liver injury that occurs in pediatric patients on PN and may progress to end-stage liver disease in 10% of affected patients. Recurrent catheterrelated bloodstream infections are relatively common in pediatric patients with SBS and IF. Other complicationrelated central venous catheters including occlusions may require intervention. » Treatment & Prognosis Goal in management of SBS is to promote growth and adaptation while minimizing and/or treating complications of the underlying intestinal disorder or PN therapy. Intestinal rehabilitation for the child with SBS and IF refers to the multidisciplinary team approach to individual patient care, involving gastroenterology, nutrition, and surgery, and has been shown to improve outcomes. Enteral nutrition should be catered to favor absorption, commonly requiring continuous delivery of an elemental formula through a gastrostomy tube. Commonly prescribed pharmacologic adjuncts include acid suppressive therapy, antimotility and antidiarrheal agents, and antibiotics for the treatment of small bowel bacterial overgrowth. Emerging therapies targeted to promote bowel adaptation include glucagon-like peptide 2 analogues, which show promise in potentially increasing absorption and bowel adaptation in ongoing trials. Management for the patient with SBS and IF should include strategies to manage or prevent complications related to PN therapy, including infection and liver disease. Antimicrobial lock solutions distilled into central venous catheters using either ethanol or antibiotics may have a role in reducing infection rates. Compelling evidence over the past several years suggests that modification of parenteral lipid solution, either through reduction in dose of soy-based intralipid or replacement with a third-generation lipid solution (Omegaven or SMOF lipid), improves outcomes associated with PNALD in pediatric patients. Current outcome data after pediatric intestinal transplantation suggest 1- and 3-year survival rates of 83% and 60%, respectively.

docs.text: Sudden Infant Death Syndrome Causes and prevention RF: 1 and 4 months old, M>F, fall, winter and early spring months. babies who sleep on stomach or their side rather than their back overheating while sleeping too soft a sleeping surface , with fluffy blankets or toys 3x: mothers who smoke during pregnancy 2x: exposure to passive smoke from smoking by mothers, fathers mothers < 20y babies born to mothers who had little, late, or no prenatal care premature or low birth weight babies having a sibling who died of SIDS Triple risk model underlying (e.g., brainstem) abnormality - unable to respond to low oxygen or high carbon dioxide blood levels triggering event such as sleeping face down on its tummy during a vulnerable stage in the infant’s development , e., the first 6 months of life Prevention putting your baby to sleep on his back using a firm sleep surface and keeping fluffy blankets and stuffed animals out of his crib not overheating your baby or his room when he sleeps not smoking when you are pregnant and not allowing anyone to smoke around your baby breastfeeding Respiratory physiology Children have a proportionately large head and a big occiput compared to their body size until ~6y  larger anatomical dead space than older children and adults. Neonates have a proportionally smaller oral cavity and a large tongue with a flat dorsal surface and limited lateral mobility  ↓size of oral cavity  airflow obstruction during sleep or under sedation. Neonates and young infants have long omega-shaped epiglottis horizontally positioned high in the pharynx very near to the soft palate than in older children and adults + absence of paranasal sinuses, this causes less resistance to airflow in the nasal passages than in the oral route. Trachea in preterm and term infants is short and narrow and more compliant than in older children and adults because of the presence of immature cartilages. Neonates, especially premature ones, have fewer alveoli - lack interalveolar communications and remain at risk of collapse and may produce atelectasis in dependent areas of the lung. In young children, intercostal muscles are poorly developed and less effective as the accessory muscles of respiration. Ribs are horizontally aligned from the vertebral column and cannot increase the cross-sectional area of the thorax during inspiration , unlike older children and adults. inspiration occurs almost entirely because of diaphragmatic descent and the diaphragm bears all the workload of breathing in neonates and infants . To reduce diaphragmatic workload and maintain minute ventilation, these children then breathe rapidly with smaller tidal volumes . However, the diaphragm has less type-1 muscle fibres and is prone to early fatigue Young infants have markedly low total lung (TLC) and functional residual capacity (FRC). Closing volume is higher than the FRC because of the highly compliant thoracic wall and poorly compliant lung tissue, which tends to cause air trapping in alveoli because of early closure of the terminal airways. Infants modify respiratory mechanics to maintain small airway patency and thus increase FRC by controlling expiratory flow through the larynx (auto-PEEP) and with the help of activity of inspiratory muscles post inspiration.

docs.text: Phenylketonuria AR inherited disorder ↑ phenylalanine (excreted as phenylpyruvate )– PAH (liver catalyses conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine) severely reduced or absent. Very common in Turkey, 1/50 NSW is a PKU carrier. Risk offspring will have PKU is 1/100 if one parent is a known carrier. It is found in all proteins and in some artificial sweeteners . If PKU is not treated , phenylalanine can build up to harmful levels competing with tyrosine and tryptophan for entry to brain (precursors of impt transmitters)  ID etc. ↑phenylalanine during catabolic illnesses. Most severe form: Infants with classic PKU appear normal (mother metabolises) until few months old . Without treatment, these children develop permanent ID, seizures, delayed development, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders 1%: co-factor tetrahydrobiopterin is not deficient in classical PKU. Untreated individuals musty or mouse-like odor , lighter skin and hair than unaffected family members, eczema, spasticity, tremors, abnormal gait, seizures, autism. Babies born to mothers who have PKU and uncontrolled phenylalanine levels have a significant risk of ID, low birth weight and grow more slowly than other children , heart defects, microcephaly, and behavioral problems. Rx: strict diet with limited protein Newborn screening: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia Congenital Hypothyroidism (CH) Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Fatty acid oxidation defects Galactosaemia Homocystinuria (cystathionine synthase deficiency) Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) - smell Organic acidopathies Primary immune deficiencies (Pilot study) Phenylketonuria (PKU) SMA (Pilot study) Tyrosinaemia types I and II Urea cycle disorders

docs.text: Turner’s Syndrome Females: 45XO Signs and symptoms: short stature (apparent by 5), premature ovarian failure, "webbed" neck a low or indistinct hairline in the back of the head swelling (lymphedema) of the hands and feet broad chest and widely spaced nipples arms that turn out slightly at the elbow congenital heart defects or heart murmur – coarctation, truncal scoliosis (curving of the spine) or other skeletal abnormalities kidney problems - horseshoe an underactive thyroid gland ↑risk of diabetes, especially if older or overweight osteoporosis due to a lack of estrogen Most affected girls and women have normal intelligence , but some have developmental delays, learning disabilities, and/or behaviour problems. Treatment: GH for short stature and estrogen therapy to help stimulate sexual development.

docs.text: Allergic rhinitis Allergic rhinitis (AR), or rhinoconjunctivits, is the commonest allergic disease in older children, affecting 15% of young teenagers. **** Poorly controlled AR is associated with a significant –ve impact on quality of life, school attendance and performance, and sleep disturbance. **** AR is a risk factor for asthma development. **** AR and asthma often coexist, with up to 75% of older asthmatics reporting rhinitis symptoms. **** AR impairs asthma control, and therefore, management of AR should be optimized in asthmatics. Symptoms **** Nasal: rhinorrhoea (clear or yellow), nasal congestion and obstruction, itching, sneezing, nasal voice, snoring. **** Ocular: itching, lacrimation, redness, lid oedema. **** Lower respiratory tract: cough, wheeze, SOB. Diagnosis: taking an aeroallergen history History should focus on elucidating symptoms and their impact on life, atopic family history, and the presence of other atopic disorders. An aeroallergen history should focus on: **** Seasonal variation: perennial symptoms suggest house dust mite allergy; symptom onset in early spring suggests tree pollen allergy, and late spring/summer symptoms suggest grass pollen allergy. **** Presence of a furry pet (within the household, but also regular exposure elsewhere). **** Exposure to moulds (household/rural environments). **** Change in symptoms on exposure to new environments (e.g. on holiday). Examination **** Presence of ‘allergic salute’ (i.e. with horizontal nasal crease), allergic shiners. **** Chronic mouth-breathing. **** Presence of nasal polyps. Investigations These are usually limited in nature, but SPT/sIgE testing may be appropriate to help determine the responsible allergen. Management Allergen avoidance **** House dust mite: encasing bedding in hypoallergenic covers; removing carpet, soft furnishings, and soft toys from the bedroom; humidity reduction in the bedroom; regular hovering. **** Pollen: minimize outdoor activity when high pollen counts—early morning and early evening; keeping windows closed; showering after exposure; wearing sunglasses; applying nasal balms. **** Pets: removal of the pet or minimize contact. **** Nasal saline irrigation is of benefit, if tolerated. Fluticasone and mometasone are preferred because of minimal systemic bioavailability. **** Administration technique should be reviewed. **** Regular use of second-generation non-sedating antihistamines, e.g. cetirizine or fexofenadine (least sedating). **** Commencing treatment 2wk before a known allergen season improves treatment efficacy. **** For severe nasal congestion, short-term use of nasal decongestant, alongside intranasal steroids, can improve drug penetration. **** Leukotriene receptor antagonists can be used as add-on therapy. **** Topical treatment with antihistamines or chromones is indicated for conjunctival disease. **** For severe cases, allergen immunotherapy can be considered.

docs.text: Allergic rhinitis (AR), or rhinoconjunctivits, is the commonest allergic disease in older children, affecting 15% of young teenagers. **** Poorly controlled AR is associated with a significant –ve impact on quality of life, school attendance and performance, and sleep disturbance. **** AR is a risk factor for asthma development. **** AR and asthma often coexist, with up to 75% of older asthmatics reporting rhinitis symptoms. **** AR impairs asthma control, and therefore, management of AR should be optimized in asthmatics.

docs.text: Allergy Allergy: terminology and tests Terminology in paediatric allergy **** Allergy: a disordered reaction by the immune system to a non-toxic antigen. **** Atopy: the predisposition to produce allergic responses. **** Allergic disease: includes eczema, food allergies, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. Atopic diseases are common—worldwide 1 in 8 children have asthma, 1 in 13 eczema, 1 in 12 food allergies, and 1 in 8 allergic rhinitis. **** Allergic reactions: either IgE-mediated (type I hypersensitivity reactions) or from a mixture of other inappropriate hypersensitivity reactions (labelled ‘non-IgE-mediated’ for practical purposes due to the complexity of unpicking the precise immune mechanisms in a child). **** IgE-mediated reactions: allergen-specific IgE antibodies bind to mast cells via their Fc receptor. Soluble antigens (allergens) bind to the specific IgEs (sIgEs). This results in IgE cross-linking and mast cell degranulation with histamine release. **** Intolerance: a non-immune (i.e. not allergic) set of symptoms to noxious substance, e.g. lactose-inducing loose stools and flatulence after a bout of gastroenteritis. **** Sensitization: the presence of circulating sIgE for a given antigen which may or may not then lead to allergic reactions. **** ‘Allergic March’: refers to the progression and general evolution of allergic diseases throughout childhood. Eczema (infancy) → food allergy (early childhood, age 1–2y) → asthma (childhood, age 5y onwards) → allergic rhinitis (later childhood, 7+y). Allergy tests **** The two main tests available are blood-specific IgEs and SPT; both are equally valid means of testing IgE levels to a specific antigen. **** These tests should only be performed after a detailed allergy history is taken, which will help direct what allergens to test against and determine a pre-test probability of the test confirming genuine allergy. **** The tests should be interpreted by clinicians with competencies in the field. **** Presence of a +ve test merely indicates sensitization to the allergen and in isolation does not confirm clinical allergy. Specific IgE levels - sIgE levels are measured in serum, a test usually accessible from primary care. Many hundreds of antigens can be tested. - **** Positive predictive values (PPVs) of 95% are used as reference - A high sIgE level makes an allergy more likely but does not always correlate to the severity of the allergic response. It therefore should not be used as a predictor of anaphylaxis risk. Skin prick tests **** This involves placing a droplet of allergen containing solution on the skin, then using a small lancet to prick the epidermis. **** After 15min, the skin is inspected for the presence of a wheal, and the average diameter of the wheal calculated. **** A +ve (histamine) and –ve (saline) control are used. **** The test is painless and can be performed from infancy onwards. **** PPVs of 95% for SPT are given **** Oral antihistamines must be stopped 3 days before testing. **** Contraindications include dermatographism and moderate to severe skin disease. **** Testing should only be performed by trained personnel, in facilities equipped to manage a possible anaphylactic reaction (very rare). **** Prick-to-prick testing (pressing the lancet into the food prior to pricking) can be used if an allergen solution is not available. A large wheal makes an allergy more likely but does not correlate with the severity of the allergic response. It therefore cannot be used as a predictor of anaphylaxis risk. Food allergy Food allergy in childhood is common, affecting 6–8% of children aged <3y. The commonest food allergies in early childhood are milk and egg. One to 3% of young children have cow’s milk allergy. In later childhood, allergies to peanuts and tree nuts predominate. Other common allergens are fish, shellfish, wheat, and soy. Food allergy versus food intolerance Food intolerance is a non-immunologically mediated adverse reaction to food. It includes: **** Enzyme deficiencies, e.g. lactase deficiency. **** Pharmacological, e.g. tachycardias in heavy tea/coffee drinkers due to caffeine. **** Sensitivity to vasoactive amines in food, causing localized reactions such as lip swelling, e.g. cured meats, cheeses, fish, ripe bananas, oranges, tomatoes, strawberries. **** Toxin-mediated, e.g. scrombroid poisoning (histamine from spoilt fish), food poisoning. **** Chemical effects (gustatory rhinitis with hot/spicy foods). **** Irritant reactions. **** Infectious syndromes, e.g. food poisoning or acute urticaria with viral illness. Taking a food allergy history Careful history taking is important in a diagnosis of allergic disease, because it helps to differentiate allergic from non-allergic reactions, to identify potential triggers, and to direct investigations. **** Presenting symptoms: focus on gut, skin, and respiratory systems to differentiate IgE from non-IgE-mediated reactions (see Table 13.1 ). **** Timing of the reaction from ingestion. **** Previous exposure to the allergen and severity of reactions. **** Detailed feeding history, including breastfed/bottle-fed; weaning; foods avoided and why. **** Exposure to other common allergens (see Table 13.2 ): if they are being consuming regularly, there is no need to test for those allergens. **** Whether the reaction was preceded by exercise, viral illness, or alcohol consumption (as these can lower the threshold for reaction). **** History of other atopic diseases, including infantile eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. **** Family history of atopy. Allergy testing in food allergy IgE levels to a specific food allergen are influenced by three key factors which must be borne in mind when interpreting the results and using them to estimate if true allergy exists or not: **** Age of the child. **** Length of time since last exposure. **** Type of allergen. Diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated food allergy There is no single diagnostic test for non-IgE-mediated food allergy: **** Use a 4wk exclusion period and assess symptom resolution. **** Then re-introduce any of the suspected allergens into the diet, even if improvement in symptoms is seen. **** Allergy is then confirmed and diagnosed if symptoms recur.

docs.text: Drug allergy Drug allergy is an immune-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to a medicinal product. In children, prevalence of a self-reported drug allergy is between 3% and 7%. Up to 95% of children with a plausible history of drug allergy are, in fact, able to tolerate the drug on re-challenge. Drug allergies should be investigated as they can lead to lifetime use of less effective and more costly treatments: **** Children with chronic conditions requiring regular antibiotics, e.g. CF, are at higher risk of sensitization and allergy. **** Atopy is not a risk factor for a drug allergy per se but may lead to more severe reactions. **** Cutaneous reaction is the most commonly reported sign, but often due to the underlying illness, rather than the drug administered. **** β‎-lactam compounds and NSAIDs are the most encountered drug allergies, with penicillin accounting for 75% of fatal drug-induced anaphylaxis cases. Diagnosis Detailed history taking is key to focusing on drug formulation, route and dose, time course and pattern of reaction, and history of relevant previous exposure: **** If an anaphylactic-type reaction is witnessed, a serum tryptase sample should be taken 1–2h after onset of reaction. **** SPT can be performed if IgE-mediated allergy is suspected using the specific drug implicated. SPT may be falsely –ve in up to 30% of penicillin allergies. **** sIgE is available for certain drugs (e.g. penicillins). It is useful if +ve, but results are usually –ve and hard to interpret. **** Intradermal or patch testing can confirm a delayed/T-cell-mediated reaction, e.g. drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) or SJS, but are difficult to perform in children. **** Drug provocation testing can be performed, but only by experienced personnel in adequate facilities. Intradermal inoculation at tiny doses (e.g. 1/1000 dose) can be used if an IV drug allergy is suspected. It can exclude drug sensitivity or confirm a diagnosis. For possible delayed reactions, a prolonged course of the drug should be given for several days following an in-hospital challenge. Management **** Manage the immediate reaction by stopping the culprit drug and administering any required treatment. **** Provide written information to the patient and all health care providers regarding which drug to avoid. **** Ensure drug allergy is highlighted in hospital and GP notes. **** Engraved allergy-bracelets can be used. **** Adrenaline autoinjectors are not routinely prescribed if the causative drug has been identified and is easily avoided.

docs.text: Food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) FPIES is a rare non-IgE-mediated food allergy occurring classically in infants and young children. **** Acute FPIES occurs a couple of hours post-food ingestion and is characterized by repeated vomiting, lethargy, pallor, and hypothermia. **** 15% are at risk of hypovolaemic shock. **** Sepsis is a possible differential, and it is not uncommon for these children to be treated repeatedly for sepsis before diagnosis. **** Acute management is focused on aggressive fluid rehydration. **** Common allergens are cow’s milk, wheat, rice, and soybean. **** Chronic FPIES is rare and presents with repeated vomiting, loose stool, FTT, iron deficiency anaemia, and hypoalbuminaemia. **** A trial elimination diet results in improvement of symptoms, as no diagnostic tests are available. **** Oral food challenges can be performed to either confirm the diagnosis or assess for FPIES resolution. **** Oral food challenges are high risk and must be physician-supervised and IV fluids must be readily available.

docs.text: Hereditary angio-oedema Due to mostly hereditary C1-esterase inhibitor deficiency: **** AD, so family history may be present. **** Attacks begin in later childhood and can be precipitated by trauma, infections, hormonal changes, and emotional stress. It does not cause urticaria. **** Typically, C4 and C2 levels are low between attacks and undetectable during an attack; C1-inhibitor levels can also be low. **** Treat major attacks with purified/recombinant inhibitor and supportive care as needed. Prophylaxis can be with modified androgens (e.g. danazol) or anti-fibrinolytics (tranexamic acid).

docs.text: Mastocytosis Includes a range of disorders characterized by accumulation of mast cells: **** Cutaneous mastocytosis: urticaria pigmentosa—itchy brown macules, with urticaria developing on scratching these (Darier’s sign). **** Systemic mastocytosis: involves the gut, bone, and bone marrow and can present with abdominal symptoms, flushing, palpitation, headaches, SOB, and malaise. Differential diagnosis includes phaeochromocytoma and carcinoid. **** Can be associated with haematological disorders: leukaemia, lymphoma, myelodysplasia. Diagnosis **** Mast cell tryptase. **** Skin/bowel/bone marrow biopsy. **** Exclusion of differentials. **** Assessment for underlying haematological malignancy. Treatment **** High-dose antihistamines. **** Leukotriene antagonists. **** Sodium cromoglicate. **** Beware use of drugs which activate mast cells (e.g. opiates).

docs.text: Venom allergy Allergy to bee and wasp venom is a common cause of anaphylaxis and may result in death. In general, children have less severe reactions than adults. **** All children with a systemic reaction to venom should be referred to an allergy specialist. **** Large local reactions are common and do not indicate venom allergy, but rather the local histamine response to venom inoculation. **** Family members of bee-keepers have sensitization rates of 30–60% to bee venom. **** Venom allergy is not commoner in atopic individuals. **** In suspected cases, sIgE to both venoms should be tested. If a double +ve result is obtained, SPT can help clarify the responsible species. **** Baseline tryptase levels should be checked, as higher levels are associated with more severe reactions. Management **** Insect avoidance measures (wear light-coloured clothing; ensure skin is covered when outside; avoid strong perfumes; don’t leave food uncovered outside, and exercise caution in outdoor areas). **** Children with a history of systemic reactions or elevated basal tryptase should have a written allergy management plan and be prescribed adrenaline autoinjectors. **** Children with a history of severe systemic reactions should be referred to a specialist allergy service for venom immunotherapy.

docs.text: Potter sequence A collection of fetal abnormalities caused by oligohydramnios. The classical triad of Potter sequence is craniofacial abnormalities, clubbed feet, and pulmonary hypoplasia. The prognosis of patients born with Potter sequence depends on the root cause of oligohydramnios but the condition is often deadly due to pulmonary hypoplasia.

His mother has brought him to see you as he has been unsettled throughout the day and now has a low-grade fever. His mother has noticed that he seems to be in pain when he is passing urine and his penis seems erythematous. docs.text: Retropharyngeal abscess General features Typically polymicrobial flora with causative organisms including GPCs, GNBs and anaerobes such as Streptococcus pyogenes Staphylococcus aureus Prevotella melaninogenicus Fusobacterium spp. Clinical features Mouth and throat pain Trismus (limited mouth opening) Hot potato voice Inability to swallow saliva and stridor suggest imminent airway compromise Fever, tachycardia, and progression to septic shock Bull neck appearance Tripod position and respiratory distress Tongue appears displaced superiorly and anteriorly, and inability to protrude the tongue Tenderness over the neck and throat Submandibular “woody” induration, crepitus or tenderness Investigations CT head and neck Management Early administration of antibiotics Metronidazole 500mg IV every 12 hours AND Benzylpenicillin 2g IV every 6 hours non-immediate hypersensitivity to penicillin: Cephazolin 1g IV every 8 hours immediate hypersensitivity to penicillin: clindamycin 450 mg IV every 8 hours OR lincomycin 600 mg IV every 8 hours Steroids Dexamethasone 8-12 mg IV initially then dose’s of 4-8mg every 6 hours for the first 48 hours initial chemical decompression by decreasing oedema and cellulitis, thus allowing improved penetration of antibiotics in the area Source control needle aspiration surgical decompression of the sublingual, submental and submandibular spaces if: airway compromise, focal collections, necrotizing infection, poor response to antibiotics

docs.text: Thyroglossal duct cyst Pathophysiology Congenital abnormality - present at any age due to failure of the thyroglossal duct to involute Clinical features Most common midline congenital neck mass Mass along midline of thyroglossal duct Examination move with swallowing if opens out into the skin → duct sinus : discharge ‘honey’ risk of recurrence (US) on excision, 1/1000 ectopic thyroid tissue → excise all of them → malignant potential Investigation transillumination US: thin-walled, smooth, well-defined homogeneously fluid-density lesions Management Asymptomatic - conservative management Surgical excision (Sistrunk's procedure)

docs.text: Pharmacological options for pain management Non-opioid therapy options First line Paracetamol NSAIDs Topical NSAIDs (e.g. diclofenac) have few systemic side effects Muscle relaxants - short course may be considered for acute pain Nonopioid adjuvants for neuropathic pain syndromes Gabapentanoids (gabapentin, pregabain) Serotonin-Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) including carbamazepine - appears to be effective in treatment of trigeminal neuralgia Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) Medical cannabis Opioid therapy options World Health Organisation analgesic ladder By the clock, by the mouth, by the ladder By the clock Aim to give analgesia as scheduled rather than PRN medications By the mouth Oral route preferred for ease of use Use the least invasive routes (sublingual, subcutaneous) before using intravenous NEVER use intramuscular routes By the ladder Escalate drugs in the following order Non-opioids (e.g. paracetamol, NSAIDs) As necessary - mild opioids (E.g. codeine): Strong opioids - e.g. morphine, hydromorphine Adjuvants may be considered at ANY point of the ladder Antidepressants (Amitriptyline) Anticonvulsants (e.g. gabapentin) Corticosteroids (E.g. dexamethasone) Anxiolytics (E.g. diazepam)

docs.text: Symptom management in pallative care Background Effective symptom management crucial to palliative care interventions Dyspnoea Background Most prominent and distressing symptom with underlying illness Goal - address underlying cause (e.g. pleural effusion, infection, anaemia, COPD, heart failure) and treat hypoxaemia Management Hypoxaemia → supplemental O2 Refractory dyspnoea → morphine reduces sensation of dyspnoea, do not cause respiratory depression or hasten death when appropriately selected and dosed Oropharyngeal secretions Background Audible oropharyngeal secretions ('death rattle') occur at end of life, distressing for families and clinicians occur in up to 50% of dying patients Management Treatment is generally ineffective antimuscarinics to decrease oropharyngeal secretions not generally recommended scopolamine, glycopyrronium, hyoscine, atropine, octreotide is not superior to no treatment anticholinergics can lead to dry mouth and urinary retention avoid deep suctioning by catheter consider raising bed/positioning of patient Nausea Background common and debilitating symptoms rated more distressing than unrelieved pain Management target towards underlying mechanism and associated neurotransmitter pathway Constipation Background common in serious illness causes include opioids dehydration immobility metabolic disturbances nonopioid medication Management prophylaxis - consider when constipation likely to occur education RE fluid intake and physical activity pharmacotherapy osmotive laxatives polyethylene glycol simulant laxative senna bisacodyl docusate alone or in combination is no more effective than placebo rectal suppository / enema preparations phosphate- or magnesium enemas contraindicated due to risk of dangerous electrolyte shift Anorexia and weight loss Background occur as part of the natural progression of life-limiting illness Management address reversible contributors to anorexia to ease patient and family distress enteral/parenteral artificial nutritional support does not improve survival, is invasive, can cause side effects (increased resp secretions, uncomfortable oedema) Depression Background grief common, clinical depression not expected should be treated aggressively Management Pharmacotherapy antidepressants appropriate for estimated prognosis SSRIs effective and safe with end-organ dysfunction, however therapeutic effects not reached for several weeks methylphenidate favoured if patients have < 6 weeks life expectancy Anxiety Background coexists with depression potential triggers existential fears uncertainty inherent to dying process difficult decisions concern for loved ones financial issues Management nonpharmacological social supports, relaxation therapy, exercise, mindfulness meditation, psychotherapy pharmacologic benzodiazepines - closely monitor for delirium SSRIs for coexisting depression Delirium Background may be reversible however cause not often identified Management non-harmacologic hydration orienting stimuli reducing noise pharmacologic little evidence for antipsychotics first generation antipsychotics (e.g. haloperidol) noninferior to newer antipsychotics

docs.text: Ankylosing spondylitis Background Chronic inflammatory disorder affecting the axial skeleton Up to 20% of those who are HLA B27 positive will develop the condition Pathology Clinical features Back pain affecting young males, typically HLA-B27 (spondylnegative) associated. Presents with loss of lumbar lordosis, chest pain, hyper-extended neck and hip/knee flexion, sacroilitis. XR shows bamboo spine and dyndesmophytes from ligamental calcification. Affected articulations develop bony or fibrous changes Typical spinal features include loss of the lumbar lordosis and progressive kyphosis of the cervico-thoracic spine Diagnostic criteria Investigations Sacro-ilitis is a usually visible in plain films Management Pain relief: NSAIDs DMARDs → ? + infliximab/etanercept Sx → Joint replacement, spinal osteotomy Prognosis

docs.text: Temporal arteritis (Giant cell arteritis) Background Inflammatory disorder of arteries frequently involving extracranial carotids Incidence: 77 / 100,000 over age 50 Average age on onset 70 years old 65% of cases are women 50% go on to develop blindness if not treated due to ischemic optic neuropathy Clinical features Headache, jaw claudication, malaise, muscle aches Gradual onset over few hours before reaching peak (occasionally explosive) 'dull and boring' pain with 'superimposed stabbing', typically superficial (unlike migraines) with scalp tenderness Tender erythematous temporal arteries Fever, weight loss Polymyalgia Rheumatica Diagnosis Bloods ESR - often raised (but not sensitive) Temporal Artery Biopsy - do not delay treatment for bx Management Prednisone 80mg OD for 4-6 weeks

docs.text: Chlamydia Trachomatis Background most commonly reported bacterial STI in USA Screening of all sexually active women > 25 years recommended, especially with STI risk factors High risk men (e.g. MSM, STI clinics) should be screened Clinical features Oropharyngeal and recal infection possible Asymptomatic and mild pulmoanry histoplasmosis resolves with treatment Diagnosis Nucleic acid amplificaiton test (NAAT) First catch urine (Men and women) - nearly identical sensitivty and specificity to swabs Endocervical swab (Women) Urethral swab (Men) Management Antibiotic therapy Antifungal therapy Itraconazole 6-12 weeks for acute infection, 12 months for cavitary pulmonary infections recommended for severe or disseminated disease liposomal amphotericin B followed by de-escalation to oral itraconazole if severe lung disease and disseminated infection

docs.text: Syphilis Background Caused by Treponema Palidum (a spirochete) Stages Primary (Chancre) - painess Secondary Latent Clinical features Chancre (ulcer in Primary Syphilis) Single, painless, well-demarcated ulcer Clean base Regular, raised, Indurated border Distribution in anogenital region (may also affect oropharynx ) Glans (35%) > Prepuce (19%) > Frenulum (10%) Regional lymphadenopathy may be present Tend to heal within 3-6 weeks Secondary syphilis Rash palmar rash / soles papules in intertriginous regions fuse to form condyloma lata mucous patches/erosions ( Gumma ) in oral cavity and moist genital regions prominent systemic symptoms and generalised lymphadeopathy common Uveitis and neurosyphilis (meningitis) Can resolve without treatment, followed by patent infection (positive serology, asymptomatic) Latent < 12 months - early latent Latent > 12 months - late latent Tertiary syphilis Stroke, altered mentation, auditory/ophthalmic abnormalities Diagnosis Reverse serological testing: Automated enzyome immunoassay → non-specific test (e.g. RPR/VDRL) Chancre testing - dark field microscopy - direct treponeme/treponema DNA detection can detect motile spirochetes but not easily accessible direct fluorescent antibody Non-treponemal tests VDRL or RPR with reflex Antibody response to cardiolipin (non-treponemal test) Titre correlates with disease activity Limitations non reactive in early primary syphilis false negatives temporary negative in secondary syphilis in HIV false positives - pregnancy, autoimmune, drug abuse, lymphoma, infectious diseases, hepatitis/cirrhosis, APLS, idiopathic Treponemal tests typically used to confirm a reactive non-treponemal test (above) Silver stain of histopathological sections skin biopsy with silver staining CANNOT be cultured Management Benzathine Pencillin G 2.4 million units (1 dose) IM if HIV positive - 2.4 million units weekly for 3 weeks Alternative options Doxycycline 200mg OD for 14 days TCH 500mg QID 14 days Erythromycin 500mg QID 14 days Ceftriaxone 250mg IM OD 10 days Contact tracing in preceding 90 days

docs.text: CT Abdomen contrast phases Background Organs such as lung and bone have a radiological density very different from the focial tumours/lesions affecting them Liver has a soft tissue/water density similar to that of tumours/lesions - plain films therefore are not able to contrast effectively Visualisation equation \(lesion_{conspicuity} = attentuation_{normal liver} - attentuation_{focal lesion}\) tumours with soft tissue density lack the attentuation difference IV contrast is used to increase attentuation difference between normal liver and focal liver lesions differential contrast impact required between lesion and liver parenchyma Non-enhanced CT (NECT) Helpful in detecting calcifications, fat in tumors, fat-stranding as seen in inflammation like appendicitis, diverticulitis, omental infarction etc. Early arterial phase - 15-20 sec p.i. or immediately after bolustracking This is the phase when the contrast is still in the arteries and has not enhanced the organs and other soft tissues. Late arterial phase - 35-40 sec p.i. or 15-20 sec after bolustracking. Sometimes also called "arterial phase" or "early venous portal phase", because some enhancement of the portal vein can be seen. All structures that get their bloodsupply from the arteries will show optimal enhancement. Hepatic or late portal phase - 70-80 sec p.i. or 50-60 sec after bolustracking. Although hepatic phase is the most accurate term, most people use the term "late portal phase". In this phase the liver parenchyma enhances through bloodsupply by the portal vein and you should see already some enhancement of the hepatic veins. Nephrogenic phase - 100 sec p.i. or 80 sec after bolustracking. This is when all of the renal parenchyma including the medulla enhances. Only in this phase you will be able to detect small renal cell carcinomas. Delayed phase - 6-10 minutes p.i. or 6-10 minutes after bolustracking. Sometimes called "wash out phase" or "equilibrium phase". There is wash out of contrast in all abdominal structures except for fibrotic tissue, because fibrotic tissue has a poor late wash out and will become relatively dense compared to normal tissue. This is comparable to late enhancement of infarcted scar tissue in cardiac MRI. All liver tumors however get 100% of their blood supply from the hepatic artery. So a hypervascular tumor will be best seen in the late arterial phase. A hypovascular liver tumor however will enhance poorly in the late arterial phase, because it is hypovascular and the surrounding liver does also enhance poorly in that phase. This tumor is best seen when the surrounding tissue enhances, i.e. in the late portal (or hepatic) phase at 75-80 sec p.i. References https://www.ajronline.org/doi/pdf/10.2214/ajr.163.2.8037023

docs.text: Iron studies Components Ferritin intracellular iron stores released into the serum in small amounts normally in inflammation (liver disease, malignancy, etc.) cells cannot hang onto their ferritin, and is released in inflammatory cascades ?release of ferritin allows other cells in need to capture ferritin and use it acute phase reactant - elevates in inflammation Serum iron Fe3+ bound to serum transferrin highly variable, affected by dietary iron intake, inflammation, infection Transferrin Iron transport protein in plasma its number is a reflection of how much iron is needed high requirement for iron (e.g. iron deficiency) = high transferrin Transferrin saturation Typically transferrin is 30% saturated with iron in majority iron overload = transferrin will be oversaturated (Where else would the iron go?) iron deficiency = transferrin will be undersaturated (transferrin increases due to increased demand - above; however not enough iron to saturate) transient increases in TF saturations can occur with rapid increased dietary intake of iron isolated transferrin elevation - repeat on fasting sample to eliminate dietary component can also rise following recent intake of iron replacement - wait ~ 4 weeks post cessation of replacement prior to assessing iron studies Total iron bindinc capacity availability of iron binding sites on transferrin effectively the inverse of transferrin saturation Interpretation Iron overload Causes primary overload (e.g. Hereditary Haemochromatosis ) secondary overload (e.g. repeat blood transfusion, iron loading anaemias, iron supplements, Porphyria Cutanea Tarda ) persistently raised TF saturation → HFE gene analysis and pre-test counselling pan-elevated iron studies can occur in acute hepatic injury due to intracellular leakage - can give impression of iron overload Iron deficiency consider measuring CRP if serum ferritin normal/high and serum iron/TFsat low as serum ferritin normally used to diagnose iron deficiency normal/high serum ferritin can be a false marker given elevation as an acute phase reactant

docs.text: Chest X-Ray Systematic intepretation Basic details Ensure correct name and date of study Read the film markers (L vs R) Evaluate the film technique (supine? AP vs PA?) Film adequacy Penetration Lower thoracic vertebrae should be visible THROUGH the heart - doesn't need great detail, but should be able to see outline Inspiration should be taken in full inspiration - should see 10th or 11th rib intersecting with right cardiophrenic sulcus Rotation Bony landmarks should be used - soft tissue (E.g. trachea) can move spinous process should be between the heads of the two clavicles if rotated, appearance of lung field can be altered, mediastinum can appear widened/displaced Completeness everything in chest needs to be seen - e.g. costophrenic angle A true chest XR should include a lateral as well ABC approach Airway Bones Cardiomediastinum Diaphragms Everything Else Line and tubes foreign bodies air under diaphragm, in mediastinal space Lung Fields Silhouette signs Loss of right heart border → right middle lobe pneumonia Loss of right hemidiaphragm → right lower lobe pneumonia Loss of left upper heart border → Lingula pnuemonia See Chest XR cases 1 Geographic approach risk of not looking at the rest of the film Targeted approach used for rule in/out in scan - only valid on uprihgt filme Thickened interlobular fissures Perihilar crowding Pneumothorax take inspiratory and expiratory views expiratory view contenses thorax content to accentuate pneumothorax image inversion makes the pleural reflection more obvious lateral decubitus (88% sensitivity), upright CXR (59% sensitivity), supine AP (37% sensitivity) deep sulcus sign on a supine CXR, air pushes the diaphragm down haziness on CXR lung field on context of trauma - consider haemopneumothorax Rib fractures image inversion Pneumomediastinum continuous diaphragm sign - can see separation between heart border and diaphragm caused by pneumomediastinum and pnemopericardium (rare) caused typically by forced expiration against closed glottis THC Cocaine Athletes Asthmatics Severe coughing Clinical vomiting - docs.text: Dressings Dressing types Moisturising Hydrogel - a jelly-like material (typically made of glycerine) containing water in a polymer matrix can provide and diffuse out H2O into wound creates a moist environment if the wound is dry creates a cooling pain/symptom relief Absorbent Alginate - sheet of felt-like material with algae polymers alginate + CMC - alginate and cellulose-based material CMC can absorb H2O Foam - porous material draws water up like a sponge Moisturising/absorbent Hydrocolloid dressing - hydrocolloid attached to thin polyurethane film absorbs moisture whilst taking bacteria from the surface and absorbs bacteria onto surface when removed, acts as mechanical debridement Protective low-adhesive dressings looks like gauze; large strands which don't really allow moisture absorbent, etc only real purpose is to prevent further abrasion to the surface Special dressings odor control dressings pad with activated charcoal antimicrobial dressings iodine/iodoform-based dressings silver-based dressings Wound management and choosing dressings Questions What is the goal How do we optimise wound What dressing do we apply

docs.text: Skin grafting Background graft vs. flap flap = tissue moved from one site of body to another, taken with its own blood supply graft is similar but without its own blood supply basically all tissues can be grafted across the body except for muscle (it is a functional unit, it will NOT regenerate, it will only form scar tissue) - muscle CAN however be moved as a flap Types of skin grafts split thickness - epidermis and some dermis harvested donor site heals within 2wk by immigration of epidermal cells in the hair follicles, and other adnexal structures in the dermis different from healing by secondary intention - will NOT cause ulcer because the dermis is left behind (and the dermis will grow to refill the graft donor) not as cosmetically good as full thickness graft, but it is easier to take (easier to survive), and will contract and become more pigmented full thickness - entire dermis harvested does not heal by itself due to loss of dermis - needs a primary closure or graft looks cosmetically better (preferred over split thickness graft) cannot be done if it is a big size graft composite graft - has skin and some other tissue e.g. cartilage or fat or hair not typically done Skin grafts cannot be placed over bare: bone tendon cartilage needs periostium, perichondrium or partenon (bare bone and cartilage do not have blood supply) Care also must be taken to prevent: graft shearing (damage to newly formed blood vessels) haematoma/seroma under graft - this can lift the graft and damage blood vessels infection tissue expansion slow expansion of a tissue stimulates mitosis and generates more tissue balloon is placed under skin and slowly expanded a permanent implant can be placed afterwards e.g. done after mastectomy for breast reconstruction Definition Relevant links Skin flaps Background local - flap from adjacent area to the wound flap from globella area over wound on medial canthal edge of nose globellar flap stited across regional - from the same region as the wound e.g. forehead flap for nose reconstruction e.g. pectoral flap raised to reconstruct neck/jaw area pedicle can eventually be discarded distant (microsurgical) e.g. abdominal tissue used to reconstruct breast tissue The reconstructive ladder

docs.text: Plantarflexion + inversion → Likely a lateral ligament complex sprain Anterior talofibular ligament, Calcaneofibular ligament, Posterior talofibular ligament Grading sprains Grade 1 - sprain or stretch - minor tears within ligament but not from edge Mild tenderness and swelling, minimal pain on bearing weight, and normal stress examination Grade 2 - incomplete tear Moderate tenderness, swelling and ecchymosis, some reduction in ROM and ability to bear weight, some laxity to stress examination Grade 3 - complete tear Severe swelling (can extend to >4cm above fibula), ecchymosis, inability to bear weight, positive stress examination (if possible to test) Syndesmotic injury ("high ankle sprain") injury to the tibiofibular syndesmosis (anterioinferior tibiofibular ligament, posteroinferior tibiofibular ligament, transverse tibiofibular ligament, interosseus membrane, interosseous ligament, inferior transverse ligament) due to an external rotation (lateral rotation of talus pushes fibula away from tibia) First aid management: RICE: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation Do no HARM: Heat, alcohol, running, massaging Analgesia with paracetamol or COX-2 inhibitors (celecoxib) can be used

docs.text: Acute Knee Pain Differentials Inflammatory Rheumatoid arthritis Crystal arthropathy Bursitis Tendinitis Degenerative Osteoarthritis Iatrogenic Recent knee injections (postinjection inflammation) Infective Acute Osteomyelitis - fevers, constitutional symptoms (in context of immunocompromise - HIV, sickle cell, diabetes, alcoholism, corticosteroid use), IVDU Septic arthritis - fever, erythema, irritable joint Vascular Haemarthrosis Bone infarct - Hx of hemophilia or sickle cell Neoplastic Pathological fracture - insidious onset, constitutional symptoms Traumatic Fracture - inability to bear weight Tendon or ligament injury Knee tendon rupture - patellar/quadriceps - unable to actively and fully extend knee Meniscus injury Patellar dislocation History Ask about constitutional symptoms - traumas can occur even in settings of pathological fractures Ask about previous surgeries - hardware can serve as nidus for infection Recent surgery (< 3 months) are at higher risk for virulent organisms (E.g. S. aureus) Delayed onset (> 6 months post-operative) are more likely less virulent organisms (e.g S. epidermidis) Recurrent fractures - increased suspicion for infection (e.g. Osteomyelitis ) and neoplasms (e.g. Osteosarcoma ) Weight bearing Fractures and Septic arthritis are less likely Investigations Gait Look Expose and compare both knees Atrophy, scarring, swelling, bowing, landmarks lacteration/wound - suggestive of an open fracture - surgical emergency! Feel Temperature Effusion Joint line tenderness - medial/lateral meniscus injuries or arthritis Neurovascular exam (pulses, sensation) Pulses must be assessed and ABI performed if uncertainty (ABI < 0.9 indicates high likelihood of vascular injury) Foot drop and dorsal numbness suggests Common peroneal nerve injury Move (passive) Range of motion Crepitus McMurray sign → Meniscal cartilage Lachman's test (Anterior drawer test) L Posterior drawer test Pivotal shift test Dial test Varus/valgus instability Locking and catching - indicates a mechanical blockage to motion (e.g. tear, mobile flaps, loose osteochondral bodies) Passive stretch test

docs.text: Ottawa ankle and foot rules for X-ray scans X- rays are only indicated if: 4 steps at ED AND 4 steps at presentation Base of 5th metatarsal tenderness OR navicular bone pain 6 cm posterosuperior to the medial OR the lateral malleolus Physical exams Assessment of gait Assesses ability to bear weight Often will have antalgic gait Anterior Drawer test assesses integrity of anterior talofibular ligament Patient sits with knee flexed to relax gastrocnemius-soleus complex + plantarflex ankle by 10º Hold heel and forcefully pull forward with one hand while stabilising the proximal leg Severe anterior subluxation = damage to this ligament Inversion stress test/talar tilt test assesses integrity of calcaneofibular ligament Patient has knee flexed, grab heel and tilt talus into varus (inversion) Tilt > 23º suggests damage to this ligament Squeeze/Hopkin’s test compress fibula/tibia in midcalf Positive = pain elicited over syndesmosis = injury to syndesmosis External rotation test stabilise leg proximal to ankle joint while grasping plantar aspect of food and externally rotating it Pain = injury to syndesmosis Note on physical examination often pain in the acute setting precludes assessment Repeat clinical examination is indicated once pain and swelling have subsided - generally after 2 weeks Fractures Inversion (supination) of ankle can cause fibular fractures Weber A - fracture distal to syndesmosis Weber B - Level of syndesmosis Weber C - proximal to syndesmosis Calcaneus fractures Anterior process of calcaneus fracture → lateral malleolar bony tenderness Base of 5th metatarsal fracture Inversion injury Pain on lateral border of foot, especially on weight bearing Zone 1 fracture - avulsion injury from proximal tubercle - heals well Zone 2 fracture - meta-diaphyseal junction - in a vascular watershed so often doesn’t heal well (prone to non-union) Zone 3 fracture - diaphyseal - also high rate of non-union

docs.text: Classifying and describing fractures Open fracture A fracture which communicates with the outer environment due to disruption of the skin and soft tissue Increased risk for Osteomyelitis Hardware infection Slower bone healing (non-union risk increased) ALL should receive antibiotics and are surgical emergencies Gustilo-Anderson Grading system (grading for open fractures) Increased grade = increased risk of infection nonunion amputation Type 1: low energy fracture wound size <1cm with minimal soft tissue damage wound is clean and free of contamination simple fracture pattern - minimal to nil comminution of bone and nil periosteal stripping w/ intramedullary (IM) nailing, average time to union is 21-28 wks Type 2: moderate energy fracture wound size > 1 cm with moderate soft tissue damage moderate contamination of the wound bed fracture pattern with moderate comminution of bone and nil periosteal stripping w/ IM nailing, average time to union is 26-28 weeks Type 3a: high energy fracture wound size > 10cm with extensive soft tissue damage extensive contamination of the wound bed fracture pattern demonstrating severe comminution of bone and periosteal stripping Local skin coverage of the fracture site is usually possible w/ IM nailing, average time to union is 30-35 weeks Type 3b: high energy fracture wound size > 10cm with extensive soft tissue damage extensive contamination of the wound bed fracture pattern demonstrating severe comminution of bone and periosteal stripping Local skin coverage of the fracture site is usually NOT possible, requires free tissue flap/rotational tissue flap for coverage w/ IM nailing, average time to union is 30-35 weeks Type 3c: high energy fracture wound size > 10cm with extensive soft tissue damage extensive contamination of the wound bed fracture pattern demonstrating severe comminution of bone and periosteal stripping 3C fractures typically require free soft tissue flap coverage Fractures of this sub-category involve major vascular injury which requires repair Describing bone injury Components of describing bony injury include: Name of bone Region of bone Pattern of fracture line: transverse, oblique, spiral, segmental, multifragmentary Presence of compression: Compression fractures where cancellous bone collapses, vertebral wedge compression fracture Presence of displacement of fracture fragments, displaced/undisplaced Type and degree of displacement Angulation translation rotation shortening Presence of pre-existing pathology Associated joint pathology, dislocation or subluxation AO (Arbeitsgemeinschaft fur Osteosynthesefragen) classification system First number defines bone injured Second number: Segment of bone (proximal metaphysis, diaphysis, distal metaphysis) Letter/number: Nature of injury Salter-Harris classification Used to classify growth plate (physis) injuries can lead to abnormal growth, growth arrest (complete or partial) complete growth arrest - length abnormalities partial growth arrest - angular deformities Classification types Simple fracture line only involving physis - seldom affects growth fracture line THROUGH physis, exiting THROUGH METAPHYSIS - seldom affects growth fracture line THROUGH physis exiting THROUGH EPIPHYSIS (intra-articular) - can affect joint surface, seldom affects growth fracture line ACROSS EPIPHYSIS and ACROSS METAPHYSIS - can cause focal fusion of physis, leading to abnormal growth Crush injury through physis - growth disturbance common injury to perichondial surface by direct trauma - rare, high chance of abnormal growth Specific descriptors Floating knee Ipsilateral femur and tibia fractures present → flail/floating knee between bony disconnections above and below injury

docs.text: Background DVT prophylaxis in orthopedic surgeries are necessary given the high risk of DVT formation See Virchow's triad General rules You should assess risk of bleeding vs. VTE risk prior to starting VTEp should go on for 6 weeks whilst a limb is immobilised VTEp with enoxaparin, fondaparinux, apixaban and dabigatran considered off-label to young people under 18 VTEp with aspirin is considered off label Scenarios Lower limb immobilisation VTEp with LMWH or fondaparinux up to 6 weeks Fragility fractures of lower limb (hip, knee, NOF) Start LWMH 6-12 hours post-operatively OR fondaparinux 6 house post-operatively Give VTEp prior to surgery if surgery is delayed Last dose LWMH 12 hours prior to OT Last dose fondaparinux 24h prior to OT Consider mechanical DVTp if pharmacological prophylaxis contraindicated Continue until patient no longer has significatly reduced mobility Elective hip VTEp with any of the following regimens LMWH for 10 days, aspirin (75mg ot 150mg) for further 28 days LMWH for 28 years with antiembolic stockings (until discharge) Rivaroxaban 10mg OD (marketing guidance) Apixaban 2.5mg BD (marketing guidance) Dabigatran (150mg or 220mg OD) starting 1-4 hours post-operatively Anti-embolic Elective knee VTEp with any of the following regimens Aspirin (75 or 150mg) OD for 14 days LWMH 14 days with antiembolic stockings til discharge Rivaroxaban Apixaban Dabigatran Mechanical DVTp Non-elective knee replacement DVTp generally not needed where total anaesthesia time < 90 minutes low risk of DVTp If DVTp is needed LWMH 6-12h post-op for 14 days Foot and ankle surgery DVTp should be considered where immobilisation occurs > 42 days total anesthesia time > 90 minutes VTE risk outweights risk of bleeding Upper limb surgery VTEp not needed if giving local or regional anaesthetic for upper limb surgery considered DVTp where total time under GA > 90 minutes operation will make it difficult for patient to mobilise References https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng89/chapter/Recommendations#interventions-for-people-having-orthopaedic-surgery

docs.text: Scoliosis Features: Consists of curvature of the spine in the coronal plane Divisible into structural and non structural, the latter being commonest in adolescent females who develop minor postural changes only. Postural scoliosis will typically disappear on manoeuvres such as bending forwards Structural scoliosis affects > 1 vertebral body and is divisible into idiopathic, congential and neuromuscular in origin. It is not correctable by alterations in posture Within structural scoliosis, idiopathic is the most common type Severe, or progressive structural disease is often managed surgically with bilateral rod stabilisation of the spine

docs.text: Seddon's 3 basic categories of nerve injury Background See Nerve Sheath Categories Neuropraxia Myelin injury but no axon/nerve sheath injury Results in temporary nerve conduction block and loss of motor/sensory function but NOT autonomic Fully recivery expected within hours to months Axonotmesis Myelin and axon injury with in tact nerve sheath Wallerian degeneration occurs with motor/sensory AND autonomic paralysis Degeneration can occur at approx 1mm/day, and affected by age and nutritional status Incomplete recovery within weeks to months - in tact nerve sheath means some axon regeneration Neurotmesis Myelon, axon AND nerve sheath injury Recovery is variable but complete, usually requiring surgery can result in permanent paralysis Wallerian degeneration Axonal degenation/injury Occurs with axonotmesis and neurotmesis but NOT neurpraxia Sunderland's classification of neurotmesis Endoneurium alone affected Endoneurium AND perineurium affected All three (endoneurium, perineurium, epineurium) affected - i.e. complete transection/avulsion

docs.text: Spina bifida Features: Non fusion of the vertebral arches during embryonic development Three categories; myelomeningocele, spina bifida occulta and meningocele Myelomeningocele is the most severe type with associated neurological defects that may persist in spite of anatomical closure of the defect Up to 10% of the population may have spina bifida occulta, in this condition the skin and tissues (but not not bones) may develop over the distal cord. The site may be identifiable by a birth mark or hair patchThe incidence of the condition is reduced by use of folic acid supplements during pregnancy

docs.text: Spondylolisthesis Features: This occurs when one vertebra is displaced relative to its immediate inferior vertebral bodyMay occur as a result of stress fracture or spondylolysis Traumatic cases may show the classic 'Scotty Dog' appearance on plain films Treatment depends upon the extent of deformity and associated neurological symptoms, minor cases may be actively monitored. Individuals with radicular symptoms or signs will usually require spinal decompression and stabilisation

docs.text: Stress fracture of the foot Background Most common sites of stress fracture in foot: metatarsals, tarsals, calcaneus Pathology Clinical features Examination bony tenderness of foot pain on percussion on foot pain on hopping on single leg calcaneal squeeze test - pain with calcaneal fracture Diagnostic criteria Investigations XR first line may fail to reveal fracture line MRI greater sensitvity provides greater prognostic information about risk of nonunion consider when plain films not revealing but high clinical probability Management Screening for bone health issues Athletic triad: low caloric intake, menstrual dysfunction, low bone mineral density High risk fracture (for nonunion) immobilisation, serial imaging surgical fixation specialist involvement Low risk fractures (non nonunion) rest, crutches, CAM boot and/or footware padding for pain-free ambulation aim to resume exercise in 8-12 weeks Follow-up XR 4/52 post injury for healing documentation resume nonimpact activities when ambulating with minimal pain Prognosis

docs.text: Trauma and fractures See - Classifying fractures - Mangled Extremity - Fat embolism syndrome - Treatment of fractures - Pathological fractures Approaching a Long bone fracture Radiographical evaluation (XR) Must also evaluate joint ABOVE and BELOW a long bone fracture In cases of traumas, ensure secondary surveys are completed History high energy fractures (energy) is the most important consideration → increased likelihood of soft tissue injury Mechanism of injury e.g. electrocution/seizures → associated with Posterior dislocation of the shoulder e.g. head on collision MVA → rapid deceleration injury → aortic dissection e.g. Fall on outstretched hand → wrist, elbow, shoulder, clavicle injuries Force involved in injury AMPLE Allergies Medications - esp anticoagulation/antiplatelets, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants Past medical/surgical history and reactions to anaesthetic agents Last eat/drink Events leading to injury Examination Assess the functional components ABC approach Look/Feel/Move (active, passive)/ Special tests for all limbs/joints Examine nerve functions PRIOR to manipulation/cast application e.g. if radial nerve function LOST after cast/brace application, the nerve should be explored Special tests in certain cases, there are common associated injuries e.g. 30% of Tibio-femoral dislocation will be associated with a vascular injury Imaging Remain vigilant post-op Compartment syndrome Crush injury risk of [[Rhabdomyolysis]] and Acute Kidney Injury Management Antibiotics ASAP (see Orthopedic antibiotics ) Surgical management Open fractures are surgical emergency - OT ASAP for irrigation and debridement with excision of devitalised skin and bone Important to be done ASAP to restore length, alignment and rotation protects surrounding soft tissue, prevents further tissue damage reduces dead space → reduces rates of infection increases recovery speed In cases where there is vascular disruption with hard signs (E.g. no distal pulses) Temporary vascular shunting should be done first Orthopedic stabilisation Definitive vascular repair last Complications Infection Iatrogenic nerve or vessel injury non-union (failure to heal) malunion (healing with improper position or alignment) instrumentation failure

docs.text: Fracture management Reduce Considerations Degree of displacement of fracture fragments If the bone were to heal in this position, would it be compatible with optimum function in short and long term? was this reduction adequate? Open reduction Surgically putting bones together by direct manipulation If acceptable closed reduction is NOT achieved or UNLIKELY to succeed → open reduction - risk of stripping intact periosteum and devitalising fracture fragments - need to consider degree of residual displacement acceptable Closed reduction Indirect external manipulation of limb manually or with fracture table articular joint surface involvement → need perfect reduction to original anatomical position purpose: restore normal joint movement in short term purpose: avoid degenerative joint disease in long term intra-articular fracture → anatomical reduction important extra-articular → restoration of mechanical alignment of joints above and below - fracture fragments need not be perfectly reduced (acceptable alignment, length, rotation acceptable) extra-articualr fracture → mechanical alignment extra-articular fractures in children have greater remodelling ability so greater displacement is acceptable Hold Consideration and goals optimise biological and mechanical environments for favourable healing conditions minimise period of disability by speedning healing process methods of holding fragments in place Plaster casts and splints traction Kirschner (K-) wires External fixation Plates and screws Intramedullary nails can consider arthroplasty where fragments cannot be held together Internal fixation Placement of instrumentation entirely within the body and under the skin with NO outside communication typically left in place permanently External fixation placement of pins or wires into the bone hardware extens outside the skin/body and commected to metal rods/rings outside the body to maintain alignment ALWAYS removed at some point due to infection risk Stability Absolute stability - no displacement or movement - achieved by accurate anatomical reduction with compression across fracture fragments desirably for intra-articular fractures Relative stability - little movement at fracture site, optimising environment for callous formation and indirect bone healing Heal Rehabilitate Tools Plaster casts and splints hold stable fracture or supplement fixation of unstable fractures (e.g. below elbow cast for distal radius fracture after K-wire fixation) Two forms of plaster casts Plaster of Paris - preferred in acute fractures backslab used given risk of sqelling in acute injuries and compartment syndrome moulding of cast 3-point moulding - used to control position often uses intact dorsal peristeal hinge to mould against often will look crooked - 'bent casts make straight bones' synthetic casting materials Splints - commercially available, provide comfort/support and easy to remove/shower/bath with Advantages of casting/splinting no wound no interference with fracture site cheap adjustable no implants to remove Disadvantages limited access to soft tissue interference with function poor mechanical stability 'plaster disease' - joint stiffness, muscle atrophy Traction Kirschner wires External fixation Plates and screws Intramedullary nails Arthroplasty General advice on fracture treatment Diaphyseal fractures Extra-articular fracture → mechanicla reduction by correcting length, alignment, rotation angular malunion → abnormal joint forces → pain and secondary degenerative joint disease generally well suited to intramedullary fixation techniques Metaphyseal fractures AO A: extra-articular joint congruity not an issue mechanical alignment, length, rotation need to be considered less predictable with intramedullary nailing - therefore use plate and screws, or external fixation (or K-wires in smaller joints) consideration given to stable fixation to allow early joint movement and rehabilitation Intra-articular fractures AO B: Partial articular and AO C: Complete articular principle of treatment - anatomical reduction of articular surface, rigid stabilisation Aim: allow early joint movement, avoid degenerative joint disease Considerations: increased wound complications of open surgery, devitalised bone fragments, excessive bone exposure Osteoporotic intra-articular fractures - though anatomical reduction MAY be achieved, rigid fixation may cut out of soft bone - would consider using bone substitutes to fill bone voids and augment fixation stable fixation not possible - consider non-operative treatment and delayed joint replacement can also consider primary joint replacement AO C: Complete articular, where articular sruface has separated from metaphysis articular surface initially anatomically reduced with temporary K-wires or lag screws then articular block reattached to the shaft

docs.text: Forearms Distal radius fractures Functional anatomy composed of 3 concave articular surfaces Scaphoid fossae Lunae fossae Sigmoid notch Stability maintained by intrinsic and extrinsic ligaments primary intrinsic ligament injuired is the Scapholunate most common intra-articular sift tissue injury is the TFCC (NOT scaphoid ligament) treated non-operatively unless DRUJ unstable Distinct groups injured Young - high energy Elderly - low energy Normal paramters 11mm radial height 22 degrees radial inclination 11 degrees volar tilt Treatment Non-operative Non-displaced/reduced fractures with OK alignment risk of extensor pollicus longus rupture 3-4 months down the track treatment - transfer from Extensor indicus to extensor pollicus longus tendons Age is primary determinant to maintain fracture alignment In Patients > 65 operative - improve gripstrength and improved XR, but no difference in functional outcomes Operative intra-articular distacement > 2mm Post-reduction radial shortening > 3mm (risk of ulnar impaction) Dorsal tilt > 10 degrees from neutral Issues Dorsal plating - risk of extensor tendon irritation/rupture (e.g. EPL) Volar plating - risk of flexor tendon irritation/rupture (e.g. FPL, FDP index, EPL if screws long) External fixation - carpal complex regional pain from over distraction acute and delayed carpal tunnel syndrome → need to release carpal tunnel CRPS - 50 days vitamin C 500mg PO QD can reduce incidence potentially Fractures Radius and ulna fractures
