docs.text: Distal radius fracture Common mechanisms Injury syndromes OA A (Extra-articular) volar displacement: Smith's fracture can be close reduced, however tend to be unstable and displace if held in cast tend to reduced and held with a volar buttress plate (internal fixation) dorsal displacement: Colles' fracture closed reduction and casting some can slip/collapse with cast, so close review for first few weeks advocated initial displacmeent and dorsal comminution at risk of early and late collapse patient may choose to have surgical reduction and fixation with K-wires, plate/screw fixation or external fixation OA B/C (intra-articular) - Barton fracture anatomical reduction of joint surface - <2mm gap acceptable predictable distal radius failure - splitting of lunate fossa fragment in coronal plane and separation of radial styoid closed reduction can be achieved with manipulation fracture fragments can then be held with K-wires, plates and screw fixation or external fixation most commonly managed with closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation with 4-6 weeks in plaster cast Management Prognosis and concerns

docs.text: Fat embolism syndrome Background Occurs in 15% of polytrauma patients Particularly associated with fractures of marrow-containing bone Femur Pelvis Pathophysiology Fracture of long bone (or from surgical intramedullary rodding) → fat/marrow embolism into bloodstream Clinical features Onset between 24-72h post-trauma Triad respiratory symptoms/distress - hypoxemia, dyspnoea, tachypnoea neurological changes - confusion, drowsiness, aLOC, seizure or paralysis reddish-brown petechial rash (50-60%) - from extravasation of erythrocytes secondary to occlusion of dermal capillaries by fat emboli Management Minimise risk by early stabilisation of long bone fractures within the first 24h Supportive care including ventilatory support with high PEEP

docs.text: Knee tendon rupture Background Pathology Clinical features Anterior knee laxity → ACL disruption Varus knee instability → MCL disruption Valgus instability → LCL disruption McMurray sign Diagnostic criteria Investigations Management Prognosis ACL rupture Background 4-5x more common in women likely due to smaller ACL and intercondylar notch, landing mechanisms (more valgus/extension on landing) and muscular imbalance (lower hamstring:quadriceps strength ratio) Pathology Contact pivoting injuries direct blow to knee (e.g. lateral or hyperextension blow to knee) occurs (E.g. with helmet in football) Non-contact pivoting injuries (MORE COMMON) football, basketball, soccer associated with awkward landings Clinical features Commonly associated with a 'popping' noise due to high ligamental tension prior to tear positive Lachman's test (Anterior drawer test) ) Diagnostic criteria Investigations XR of knee Segond fracture is pathognomonic MRI is best technique to evaluate ACL integrity Management Non-operative (conservative management) IF Partial tear + nil instability Complete tear + nil instability on low-demand sports + giving up high demant sports do light manual work or live sedentary lifestyles advanced osteoarthritis significant comorbidities precluding surgery Non-operative management includes activity modification, bracing, PT (muscle strengthening) can lead to abnormal knee motion, increased future meniscal injury risk Surgical management includes arthroscopic reconstruction of ACL (tendon graft in bone tunnel) Repair of the native ligament DOES NOT HEAL due to (1) intra-articular location and (2) synovial fluid inhibiting healing Graft selection Autograft - from patient (bone-patellar, tendon-bone or hamstring tendon) decreased risk of disease transmission or immunologic reaction, faster incorporation donor-site morbidity (e.g. anterior knee pain, weak knee flexion, pain with hamstring graft), longer operating times Allograft - from cadaver prevents donor-site morbidity risk of disease transmission - though processed by freezing/irradiating Consideration needs to be made for adolescents as ACL surgery will risk growth plate damage and physeal arrest Prognosis Surgical risks include postoperative infection, Septic arthritis (can damage cartilage and result in early Osteoarthritis ) knee stiffness local saphenous neuroma formation (due to surgical incisions and graft failure) PCL rupture Background Pathology Dashboard knee injury (MVA) whilst knee flexed resulting in anterior force on flexed knee Clinical features associated with positive Posterior drawer test Diagnostic criteria Investigations Management Prognosis Unhappy triad of the knee MCL, ACL and medial meniscus combination injury Patellar tendon rupture Clinical features Patella alta → patellar riding high due to unopposed pull of quadriceps Quadriceps tendon rupture Clinical features Patella baja → patella riding low due to unopposed pull of patella tendon

docs.text: Sexual Health Case 1: ES Emily is a 20 year old University student in Armidale who presents to the University Health Service. She has a new partner and they have decided to undergo a sexual health check before taking their relationship any further. She is requesting ‘test me for everything’ What is the first step in conducting a sexual health check? Take a sexual history to determine risk Sexual History Questions to Ask: I’d like to ask you some questions about sex so we can decide what tests to do. Is that ok? When was the last time you had sex? 3 weeks ago Who have you been having sex with? My ex Have you had sex with anyone else? One other boyfriend, couple of hook ups in between How did you have sex (Vaginal sex/oral sex/anal sex) ? Vaginal and oral Did you use a condom? Couple of times no, one of the one night stands no In the last 3 months, how many sexual partners have you had? Just my ex Have you ever been diagnosed with (or thought you had) an STI? No way I’d like to ask you about some other activities that could increase someone’s risk of some sexually transmitted infections and blood-borne viruses, is that ok? Have any of your male partners ever had sex with men? Not that they told me! Have you had sex with other women? Nope Are you pregnant? No way! Implanon 3 months ago Have you ever been paid to have sex? No Have you ever had any tattoos? If yes, was that here or overseas? Small butterfly on my shoulder, in Armidale Have you ever injected drugs? No What else should be done for Emily? Has she had a cervical screening test, if so when? She has had HPV vaccination in school but has never had CST Does she need a pelvic examination? As she has had HPV vaccination, is under 25 and asymptomatic she does not need a pelvis examination at this time What STI(s) should she be screened for? Chlamydia screening is recommended for all sexually active people <30 years Consider Hepatitis B, HIV & Syphilis in low risk populations (recommend test if not low risk) Consider Gonorrhoea screening in at risk groups, may be asymptomatic What tests are required to screen for these STI? How do you instruct Emily in collecting the sample? In the absence of a pelvic examination a self collected vaginal swab has better sensitivity than a first pass urine. NAAT (Nuclear acid amplication test) is performed for both Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea Self testing Self testing for NAAT is acceptable, especially when patient is uncomfortable with clinician collection or limited consultation times PCR is very sensitive Only appropriate flr asymptomatic patients Procedure Show swab to patient Label tubes with details to avoid mishandling Moisten tip of swab with saline or sterile water Put all equipment in specimen bag and hand to patient Review collection process with patient, remind to put swab inside tube, seal tube and put sealed tube inside specimen bag Results How do you relay these results to Emily? What treatment is recommended? First line treatment is either: Doxycycline 100mg PO bd for 7 days OR Azithromycin 1g PO once Is anything further required? Advise no sexual contact for 7 days after treatment is administered. Advise no sex with partners from the last 6 months until the partners have been tested and treated if necessary. Contact tracing. Provide patient with factsheet. Notify the state/territory health department. Follow up It is now 5 months later and Emily returns to see you She is upset and appears to be in pain Emily reports that she has been going out with her current boyfriend over the last 3 months. They started having regular sex about 2 months ago, after she was cleared from reinfection of Chlamydia Over the last 2 days she has developed a burning itch over her vulva. She has some stinging when she passes urine and feels generally unwell. Is there anything further you would like to know? Blisters and sores began to appear yesterday, very painful with a burning, stinging Never had these before Had sex about a week ago, Mark (boyfriend) was well, she didn’t notice any sores or spots on his penis What are your differential diagnoses? Genital Ulcers are most commonly secondary to herpes infection (HSV-1 or HSV-2) Differential STI include Syphilis (not usually painful), lymphogranuloma venerum and donovanosis Non infectious causes include drug eruptions, aphthous ulcers, trauma, carcinoma Examination On Examination: Abdomen soft and not tender Tender inguinal lymph nodes bilaterally ^ Image from STI atlas (www.stiatlas.org) You deroof one of the lesions and take a swab of the fluid Once she is dressed again you tell her that it is most likely genital herpes as the cause. Emily is upset with this news. How did she get this, Mark was fine when they had sex? Viral shedding can occur in the absence of symptoms or vesicles Genital herpes can be secondary to HSV-1 or HSV-2 What is the recommended treatment and what advice do you need to give Emily now? Valaciclovir 500mg PO bd for 5-10 days (may require longer in initial episode) Simple analgesia, saline baths, topical lignocaine may help for symptoms Condom use regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms with partners Case 2: JB Presenting medical complaint John Bloom is a 24 year old man who comes to see you for the first time. He is obviously embarrassed is requires some gentle prompting to tell you why he is here. He eventually tells you he has a ‘spot’ on the end of his penis that has grown over the last couple of weeks. Its not painful, but it isn’t going away John is a ‘FIFO Worker’ at one of the mines in Queensland (Fly-In-Fly-Out). He works 4 weeks on 4 weeks off and lives in the single-persons quarters at the mine. He is single but admits to having ‘a bit of a good time when is on his time off’ He reports having sex with 2 different women during his last time off. He shrugs and says that he can’t remember their names and hasn’t had any contact with them since. On examination On examination: Lesion just proximal to the glans, on the dorsum of the penile shaft. No exudate on the lesion No discharge from the urethra is noted Mild bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy ^ From UpToDate Consult You tell Jon that you think he may have Syphilis and you would like to start him on treatment. You send him for a blood tests: Syphilis Enzyme Immunoassay (EIA) then Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR) test Treponema pallidum specific antibody test. What is the recommended treatment for Syphilis? Benzathine penicillin 1.8g IM once Are there any other tests you would recommend Jon have? One STI indicates risk for others, Jon should be tested for Chlamydia, Gonorrohea, and HIV If he has not had Hepatitis B vaccination he should be screened for HBV and offered the vaccination What else should you discuss with Jon? Syphilis is a notifiable disease and contact tracing needs to be performed Investigations Consult continued You give Jon 1.8g benzathine penicillin IM as a single dose You also recommend to Jon that he have testing for other STI. He doesn’t initially think that this is necessary, but agrees to after further discussion. Jon tests positive to Chlamydia but negative to HIV, Hepatitis B and Gonorrhoea He tries to recall the names of the women he had intercourse with but can only remember their first names – Sally and Hannah. He says he will keep an eye out for them next time he goes out. You inform Jon his infection must be notified to the Public Health Unit. You reassure him that the notification is entirely confidential, but a legal necessity. There is an anonymous SMS service that can inform sexual partners of STI diagnoses and risk: https://letthemknow.org.au You discuss with Jon his current safe sex practices and review strategies for improving them. Case 3: CM Presenting complaint Casey is a 30 year old single woman who attends your clinic complaining of a sore throat. It has been painful for 3 days now and she is starting to lose her voice. She is concerned as it is affecting her ability to work. PMHx nil Medications: Oral Contraceptive PIll SHx: Non smoker Drinks alcohol 3-4 drinks on a Friday or Saturday night Works in a call centre Examination Afebrile Tender cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally Enlarged tonsils with exudate bilaterally How would you treat Casey? You tell Casey that she most likely has a viral infection and it should get better in a couple of days. You write her a medical certificate, recommend paracetamol, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication, fluids and rest and ask her to return in 3 days if she is no better. Casey returns a week later with the same symptoms. She looks tired and her voice is hoarse but she continues to be afebrile. Her oropharynx is unchanged As she has had a sore throat for 10 days you are concerned that she may have a streptococcal throat infection You take a swab of Casey’s tonsils to confirm your suspicions You prescribe phenoxypenicillin and once again ask her to return if she does not improve Follow up 6 weeks pass and Casey returns The culture from the throat swab was negative for group A streptococcus She is essentially unchanged, the hoarse voice and lymphadenopathy remains Casey now discloses to you that although she does work in a call centre she also works as a sex worker part time. She is adamant that she always practices safe sex with a condom. Does this change the differential diagnoses? You are suspicious that her sore throat could be secondary to Neisseria gonorrhoea and decide to take a swab. You decide to commence treatment for N gonorrhoea You recall that there are difficulties with emerging resistance of Gonorrhoea and treat Casey with 500mg ceftriaxone IM and 1g azithromycin PO You also recommend to Casey that she have testing for other STI. Swab confirms Neisseria gonorrhoea that is sensitive to ceftriaxone. HIV, Syphilis, Chlamydia and Hepatitis B testing is negative Microbiology Intracellular Gram negative diplococci, suggestive of N gonorrhoea Contact tracing Casey discloses that there may have been occasions where she engaged with unprotected masturbation games with clients You ask Casey to provide a list of her clients over that 8 weeks so that they may be contacted and appropriate treatment commenced. http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au

docs.text: Module 11 - Anaemia Case 1 Crystal is a 35 year trans female who presents with a 12 month history of diarrhoea, tenesmus and flatulence. She has unintentionally lost 10kg over the year. There has been no fever, no recent travel, no nausea or vomiting. She is 8 years post her transition, is in a stable relationship. Examination is unhelpful. Investigations show an iron deficiency anaemia, other investigations are normal. Metastasis or active cancer increases risk of clotting 2. What score can we use to assess likely hood of PE? 3. docs.text: Module 11 - Iron studies Case 1 •Angular stomatitis- causes include oral candidiasis, bacterial infection, nutritional deficiencies (iron and vitamin B) •Atrophic glossitis- flattening of the papillae of the tongue- causes include- micronutrient deficiency- iron, vitamin B •How would you interpret these results? •Bao has microcytic hypochromic anaemia with a low red cell count, and a reticulocyte percentage that, although raised, is lower than expected for the degree of anaemia. There is also a thrombocytosis that may be reactive. •What are the major causes of anaemia associated with these findings? •Causes of microcytic hypochromic anaemia include: •Iron deficiency •Disorders of globin synthesis such as thalassaemia or another haemoglobinopathy •Disorders of porphyrin or haem synthesis (sideroblastic anaemia which may be congenital or associated with lead poisoning) •Anaemia of chronic disease may cause a microcytic hypochromic appearance •Which of these causes is most likely given the FBE results and why? •A microcytic hypochromic anaemia is most often due to iron deficiency in a patient such as Bao. His microcytosis is mild and is of an appropriate severity given the degree of anaemia. The presence of a more severe microcytosis with a lesser degree of anaemia may lead one to suspect thalassaemia. The thromboycytosis is a common finding in patients with iron deficiency and is reactive in nature. •What further testing is indicated? •Iron studies are indicated to assess for iron deficiency. The presence of thalassaemia trait cannot be ruled out without further testing or without assessing response to iron therapy if iron studies indicate an iron deficiency. •Bao had iron studies, liver function tests and CRP performed. His LFTs and CRP were normal. Interpret the results of his iron studies. •What are the most common causes of iron deficiency anaemia? •Gastrointestinal bleeding is the most common cause in Bao’s age group. The most common sites are: upper GIT- oesophageal ulceration, malignancy, haemorrhoids, colorectal neoplasia, diverticular disease, angiodysplasia, Meckel diverticulum, coeliac disease. •History should focus on- GI blood loss or melaena, weight loss, alcohol use, reflux symptoms, family history of GI cancer. •What further investigations are required for Bao? •Regardless of clinical findings that point to a specific cause for iron loss, a patient requires upper and lower GP endoscopies to exclude GI causes for blood loss, particularly malignancy. Referral to a gastroenterologist for these procedures is indicated. Case 2 •The patient has a marked macrocytic anaemia with reticulocytopenia, thrombocytopaenia and mild leucopaenia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is associated with a number of aetiologies, the most common being megaloblastic anaemia. •Clinically she has developed a peripheral neuropathy (loss of distal proprioception and vibration sense loss, loss of sense of light touch). •What are the causes of this blood picture? •Macrocytic anaemia is most commonly associated with folate or B12 deficiency (megaloblastic anaemia). Myelodysplasia is a cause of macrocytic anaemia and pancytopaenia seen in the older population. Macrocytic anaemia may also be seen in patients with excessive alcohol intake, liver disease or hypothyroidism. It is also a common finding in patients taking antimetabolite meds such as methotrexate, certain antibiotics and antiretrovirals. •Neutrophil hypersegmentation accompanies megaloblastic anaemia and therefore may occur with folate or B12 deficiency or the drugs above. •Macrocytosis is also a feature of the myelodysplastic syndromes. This may also be accompanied by neutropaenia or thrombocytopaenia. •Marked macrocytosis (>130fL) as seen in Helen’s case usually indicates B12 or folate deficiency •This results from: inadequate intake, poor absorption, or excessive utilisation (particularly for folate) •Animal products contain B12, whereas green vegetables contain folate •B12 requires an adequate acid environment in the stomach as well as secretion of intrinsic factor and a function ileum for successful absorption. Folate is absorbed in the jejumum. Before treating folate deficiency it is important to exclude concomitant B12 deficiency •What further tests are required? •B12 and folate levels •B12 ref ranges vary between labs, and with repeat samples therefore careful interpretation required •Serum folate a measure of short term folate balance, Red cell folate may better reflect long term stores, however not as reproducible as serum folate. •This patient has multiple potential causes for having a B12 deficiency. She may have gastritis from her excessive ETOH intake (which may be more than she is stating). She has been on a Proton Pump inhibitor for a long time, which can block B12 absorption. Her diet may be inadequate if she following an overly restrictive diet (such as vegan). •Students should also consider pernicious anaemia but it is beyond the scope of this tutorial to go into the detail of pernicious anaemia. It is appropriate to check for intrinsic factor antibody if her B12 level is low as this is highly specific (ie virtually diagnostic) of pernicious anaemia, but has low sensitivity. Equivocal cases should be discussed with a gastroenterologist. •Folate deficiency may be caused by poor dietary intake and alcoholism, coeliac disease or inflammatory bowel disease or the other causes previously mentioned on slide 19. Case 3 What differential diagnosis should you consider at this stage? Infection- Hep B or C, drugs, alcohol, autoimmune chronic active hepatitis, haemochromatosis Symptoms and family history suggest haemochromatosis which can cause lethargy and arthralgia The disorder can cause iron deposition in the liver (cirrhosis), skin (hyperpigmentation), pituitary (hypogonadism), pancreas (diabetes), joints (arthropathy), heart (cardiomyopathy) What further investigations should you do? Iron studies, fasting blood glucose, Hepatitis virus serology, abdo USS, coagulation studies •What is your diagnosis? •Hereditary haemochromatosis •What further investigations should be done? •Other family members should be screened •Haemochromatosis gene testing: C282Y and H63D •Liver biopsy- because of abnormal LFTs, ferritin >1000 and hepatomegaly, OR MRI to evaluate liver status •Management may include referral to a gastroenterologist, will need weekly venesection until serum iron levels return to normal (may take 2-3 years). Avoid alcohol. •His fasting blood glucose should be monitored as it is impaired. • •

docs.text: Module 12 - Geriatric syndromes Case 1: Fall, LBD Bob is a 75 year old retired university professor who presents to the GP following a fall at home the previous day Not his first fall 2/12 prior - sacral # with significant pain mechanical fall on uneven ground in garden witnessed by wife, nil LOC During rehabilitation admission after first fall neurology involvement and ?parkinsonism - started on Mx PMHx recent STML, awaiting geriatrician review knee OA diverticular disease BPH AF HTN REM sleep behaviour disorder Mx Kinson (Levodopa/carbidopa) 100/25 TDS Antiparkinsons medication / dopamine agonist Metoprolol 25mg BD Beta blocker - rate control for AF Duodart (dutasteride/tamsulosin) 500mcg/400mcg OD BPH, anti-androgen and alpha blocker Vitamin D 1000U OD Osteoporosis Alendronate 70mg Once weekly Bisphosphonate, osteoporosis Paracetamol 665mg x2 tabs TDS Analgesia, likely OA Targin (Oxycodone/naloxone) 10mg/5mg BD Analgesia, likely OA Pregabalin 75mg BD Analgesia, ?? Apixaban 2.5mg BD Anticoagulant, Xa inhibitor, AF nonvalvular Question: Which medications can precipitate a fall? Questions: What other aspects of history must be clarified? Preceding events/symptoms Post-fall symptoms Medications history - gait abnormalities, hypotension, confusion, polypharmacy Falls history - previous falls increases risk for future falls Witnesses - LOC cannot be elicited by someone who lost consciousness! What are the common causes of falls in elderly and which of these are potentially contributing in Bob? Mechanical Syncopal - cardiac or neurological Urinary incontinence Delirium Reduced balance/reaction time Sensory disturbances (vestibular, peripheral neuropathy) Weight loss / loss of muscle mass / sarcopenia MSK weakness/diseases (Arthritis, pain) Visual loss/impairment - bifocal lenses Postural drops/hypotension - may be present without medications, esp in PD Environmental Neurodegenerative diseases Concern about Bob being at risk of any complications from falls? Hip fracture On examination General exam Nil obvious distress Wearing bifocal glasses Slow to get out of chair - some grimacing(pain) during standing BP 120/75, 95/60 standing, denies dizziness HR 50, irregularly irregular RR 18, afebrile Shuffling gait, poor arm swing, nil tremor noted Questions: What else would we like to examine? Nil evidence of significant injury, nil evidence of head strike nil focal weakness, sensory exam of LL normal MMSE 28/30 (unchanged from 1/12) CV/Resp examinations normal ASNT, nil masses palpable Bilateral LL knee OA, nil effusion, nil tenderness or erythema neurological examination - sensation, vision, cardiovascular Investigations to order? FBC, EUC, CMP, LFT VB12, Folate, TFT, VitD ECG UA Outpatient geriatrician involvement scheduled for 1/52 → nil further Ix at this point Question What other things might you consider whilst Bob is in the hospital? Allied health referral PT OT Dietician Suggest optometrist visit - separate glasses rather than bifocals Geriatrician visit Bob and wife visit geriatrician in 1/52 Cognitive testing performed and medication adjustments undertaken Question What medications do you think the geriatrician is concerned with WRT falls and memory impairment? What else will the geriatrician ask about the Mx Hx? Who is administering medications Does his wife watch him take it? Does he use a webster pack? New medications? (Pain mx and kinson are new since recent admission) Cessation of medications due to AEs? Can we cease any medications which are no longer useful? Elderly patients may only need/tolerate a smaller dose compared to middle aged adults What should the geriatrician ask about the memory loss? docs.text: Thyroid function test Regulation of thyroid hormone production by HPA Role of TPO in thyroid hormone synthesis TPO oxidises iodide to form iodine iodine added to tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin Leads to production of T3/T4 Anti-TPO in throid disease may be marker and cause of autoimmune hypothyroidism (Hashimotos) Indications for performing TSH test Neonatal screening to detect congenital hypothyroidism Not recommended for screening in adults Indicated when Thyroid disease suspected (Sx consistent with hypo- or hyper-thyroidism) Hypothalamic, pituitary disease suspected (amenorrhea) In elderly - thyroid disease signs less typical, TSH measurements indicated in geriatric syndromes (functional decline, delirium, psych) monitor of patients on thyroxine replacement therapy monitor thyroid cancer treatment Medications which may adverse effect (e.g. chemotherapy, checkpoint inhibitors) Further Ix of abnormal TSH, when should T3/T4 be performed Common effects of medications of TFT Antithyroid antibodies that can be measured and explain when measurement of these indicated AntiTPO antibodies: found in autoimmune thyroid disease, indicated when thyroid disease suspected (goitre, abnormal TFTs) or when a drug is to be started which can cause thyroid disease in individuals who are antibody positive (amiodarone, lithium, interferon) Antithyroglobulin antibodies: found in thyroid cancer and Hashimotos, used to monitor cancer treatment and also indicated in hypothyroidism Antithyroid receptor antibodies: found in Graves disease, indicated when hyperthyroidism present In a pregnant woman with known thyroid disease, antibodies are indicated as can predict disease in newborn (antibodies cross placenta) Role of throid scintigraphy (nuclear medicine scanning) and indications for odering In practice, the two main applications of thyroid nuclear medicine scans are to: differentiate the causes of hyperthyroidism assess thyroid nodules when the patient has hyperthyroidism. In general, thyroid nodules less than 10 mm in diameter are usually too small to be accurately assessed with a thyroid scan. How does it fit in with ultrasound and other tests for assessment of nodules? If the patient is hyperthyroid, a thyroid scan is helpful in elucidating the function of a nodule. But if the patient is euthyroid (or hypothyroid), then a thyroid ultrasound is the preferred first line investigation. If the indication has been to differentiate between the causes of hyperthyroidism, then the pattern of uptake will provide an indication of the diagnosis (eg. Graves disease, multinodular goitre, thryoiditis), which enables an understanding of the natural history and can guide treatment. If the indication for the test was assessment of a thyroid nodule when the patient has hyperthyroidism, and the nodule is functioning (or 'hot') then treatment of the hyperthyroidism is the most likely next step. If the nodule is not functioning (or 'cold') then further investigation, such as ultrasound and/or fine needle biopsy is recommended.

docs.text: Case 2 Presenting complaint You are working as a GP registrar at a clinic in Taree. Harriet Jones is your next appointment. She has seen you a couple of times over the last few weeks with a complaint of fatigue. Harriet is a 32 year old female. She works in the local shopping centre as the store manager for a retail shoe store. She has two children – Brock aged 10 and Kylee-Ann aged 6. Harriet has been feeling exhausted for the past 4 months. She came and saw you 6 weeks ago complaining of this and requesting your assistance in fixing it. 2 children – Brock and Kylee-Ann, married to Tom who works as a car mechanic. Ex smoker – quit 2 years ago. Smoked 10/day for 10 years. Occasional alcohol on weekends – 2-3 glasses of white wine with friends PMHx childhood asthma, resolved age 15 Allergies nil Regular medications: OCP UTD vaccinations and cervical screening Her parents are fit and well Father hypertension Mother osteoarthritis knees 2/4 grandparents are still alive: Maternal grandfather had died CVA age 71 Type 2 diabetes mellitus onset age 54 Paternal grandmother passed away MVA age 52 •You took a detailed history when you saw Harriet 6 weeks ago: •She has a reasonable diet with 1 serves of fruit and 2-3 serves of vegetables every day. She eats red meat 1-2 times per week, chicken or fish on other days. •She sleeps well at night, ’better than she used to now the kids are older’. Kylee-Ann wakes maybe once per week. Harriet averages 7 hours sleep per night. •Denies night sweats •She denies daytime sleepiness, states ‘I don’t fall asleep, I’m just exhausted’. She does not snore. •Tries to exercise 3 times per week – walking the dog or going to gym but hasn’t been able to recently because of her tiredness •Her periods are regular and not heavy. Last menstrual cycle 3 weeks ago and she doesn’t think she pregnant. She hasn’t missed any of her OCP recently. •Denies any difficulties with the children – both enjoying school. She has no concerns regarding them •Acknowledges that she is frustrated with her fatigue, but denies depression •No change in bowel habits, weight stable •No rashes, joint aches or pains. •No recent travel overseas or trips camping •She was bitten by mosquitos a few weeks ago, denies any tick bites that she can recall Examination •Height 165cm, Weight 68kg BMI 25 •BP 115/72mmHg Pulse 65 regular •Random BGL 5.0 •Urine pregnancy screen negative •Afebrile •Good eye contact when conversing •Normal train of thought and flow of speech •Care taken with appearance •Mood appears normal •No conjunctival pallor, palmar creases normal colour •Not clubbed • •Oropharynx •Tonsils not enlarged, no exudate •Teeth in good condition, gingiva (gums) not swollen, pale or erythematous • •HS dual, no murmurs, no added sounds •Chest normal expansion •Clear to percussion •Normal breath sounds with no added sounds • •Abdomen soft and non tender, spleen not palpable •No palpable lymphadenopathy •No erythematous striae (long standing older marks from pregnancy • •Cranial nerves intact (CN 1 not tested) •Normal tone and power thoughout •Reflexes intact and symmetric •No tremor • •No rashes, or bruising •Skin feels supple, not dry •No joint or muscle tenderness, no effusions • You reassured her that everything seemed normal and sent her for some blood tests Questions •What would you like to do next? •· This is a good place to pause and allow to students to formulate some differential diagnoses. Should they look further? How to balance overinvestigating to avoid missing anything? What are the risks of over-investigating here? •Are further investigations warranted and if so what might be the principles guiding the choice of investigative pathway? · Whay have we ordered each test? Ask the students if this assists them in refining a diagnosis – whilst this does not point in any particular direction for diagnosis it helps rule conditions out. If they are struggling, or becoming frustrated, rephrasing the differential diagnosis question to ‘what is it not’, may help Why have we performed spirometry? (smoking history). Ask the students to describe the CXR and interpret the spirometry. Followup •She is now returning for follow up: •’Nothing has changed’ •‘I’m exhausted’ •Reviewing the history reveals no new information •Examination findings are unchanged •She has been ‘Googling’ her symptoms since you last saw her and has a list of questions: •Am I anaemic? •What about my thyroid? •Could it be Ross River fever? •Should I give up gluten? •Could I have Lyme disease? •How do you answer her questions? Further investigations What test is missing? Serum IgA level as most coeliac tests are IgA based •You explain to Harriet that whilst you have not performed every test possible for causes of her fatigue, she has had a broad range of tests that should indicate the presence of any serious underlying disease. • •You reassure her that the negative tests rule out the serious medical causes for fatigue and that in some cases it is not possible to determine an underlying diagnosis. • •Some causes of fatigue do not have a definitive diagnostic test and are a combination of a cluster of symptoms and the exclusion of other causes • •You both discuss a plan for further follow up. Harriet will try an take a little more time for herself and will endeavour to continue to get regular exercise and adequate sleep. She will return in 2 months time if her symptoms are unchanged. Ask the students if they think adequate exploration of a non-medical cause of her symptoms has been undertaken. What about her relationship with her husband?. Has this been explored? Could there be any other stressors she may now wish to talk more about now that she is aware that her concerns have been heard and addressed?

docs.text: Abdominal imaging Renal tract ultrasound Case 1 Presentation 65M with 5 month history of left flank discomfort, abdominal fullness 2/52 hx LL oedema, 4/7 Hx macroscopic hematuria with clots O/E LLQ abdominal mass, pitting oedema mid-shins bilaterally DDx Kidney mass? RCC? PKD? Ix - https://www.urology-textbook.com/renal-cell-carcinoma-diagnosis.html Labs: FBC EUC CMP LFT, LDH, AP, Coags Ix: Renal/liver ultrasound DDx cystic vs. solid mass Findings: Solid mass (outlined with dots) Further investigations Suspicious for RCC/mass - for abdominal CT w/ multiphase contrast Purpose: Determine management (Sx or chemotherapy) Help determine prognosis The findings on imaging Portal venous phase study Left kidney inferior pole partly exophytic renal mass with peripheral enhancement and central necrosis. No invasion of renal hilum Case 2 45M 1hr hx sudden left sided flank pain radiating towards groin w/ N+V BG CKD (baseline eGFR 40) DDx Renal colic - ?nephrolithasis ?PKD ruptured cyst ? flank tenderness/fever ?infection (pyelonephritis) Ix eGFR 23, otherwise all other values within normal ranges Interpretation → acute on chronic AKI Imaging CT KUB for suspected nephrolithasis - non-contrast study Alternative: Renal tract US for pregnant/pediatric Abnormality Red: Hydronephrosis Yellow: Hydroureter Green: Renal calculus Common obstructions at the PUJ, crossing of iliac vessels, VUJ Purpose of imaging in this case: Determine size and consequently if able to manage conservatively Look for complications: obstruction/hydronephrosis, perinephric stranding id suspected infection Determine type of calculus – urate versus oxalate (density, uncomplicated urate stones may be managed more conservatively) What the most appropriate surgical approach would be Case 3 56M increased abdominal girth, denies jaundice BG IVDU PE: Palpable firm liver (Hepatomegaly), shifting dullness (ascites) Ix Labs: LFT - transaminitis, hepatocellular injury Imaging request Abdominal ultrasound (liver ultrasound) +/- aspiration Alternative imaging modalities CTAP, multiphase CT The findings on imaging Red circle: Hypoechoic area, consistent with fluid, likely ascites Yellow circle and green circle: surface nodularity Splenomegaly (indicating portal hypertension) can also be seen on USS as can the portal vein (might see thrombosis and can use doppler imaging to determine direction of portal venous flow which is reversed in severe portal hypertension) Findings here are consistent with cirrhosis and ascites Further imaging CTAP - if suspicious mass found unexplained weight loss, fever, ascites without portal hypertension, or other red flags present - Red circle: area of low attenuation, consistent with fluid - Green circle: splenomegaly - Blue circle – right lobe shrinkage - Purple circle – caudate lobe hypertrophy - A ascites, D diaphragm, P pleural space Case 4 45F gradual onset N+V, constipation and abdominal distension PSHx appendectomy 2y prior PE - nil peritonism, tinkling bowel sounds Imaging to request AXR - assess bowel obstruction, fecal loading Follow with CTAP if obstructed - The findings on imaging - Confirms diagnosis of small bowel obstruction, cut off in right iliac fossa (likely adhesions) - Other features of obstruction - Lack of gas in the rectum - Discuss features of small bowel and large bowel obstruction - Normal small bowel <3cm - Normal large bowel <6cm How imaging would change management Confirm diagnosis and severity of obstruction Help determine cause Operative or non-operative management (adhesive SBO may be managed conservatively in some), help plan operative therapy Progress Admitted to ward, conservativelyt managed 16/24 - significant abdominal pain, tachypnoea, tachycardic PE - generalised peritonism DDx perforated viscus w/ peritonism Ix CXR erect can be lateral decubitus if unwell pneumoperitoneium - surgical emergency, for emergency laparotomy

docs.text: Alcoholic cirrhosis Important topics to review Acute hepatitis Chronic liver disease Alcoholic liver failure Case presentation Presenting complaint Increased abdominal distension Incoherent - concerns RE confusion Does not consistently attend practice - last presentation severeal months ago Past medical history Excess alcohol consumption Last seen and conselled RE heavy alcohol intake - not prepared to engage in intervention Last admission alcohol withdrawal Last hopsital admission 6/12 with wrist # requiring conservative management Medication history Setraline Amlodipine Social history Nobody at home to look after him Examination Confused - not oriented to person, place, time BP 145/75, HR 100 regular, RR 24, Temp 37.8 What other signs should the GP look for? Approach: Alcohol withdrawal, chronic liver disease, other causes of confusion, causes of decompensated liver disease Signs of liver failure and decompensation - asterixis (hepatic flap), spider naevi, caput medusa, jaundice, scleral icterus, gynaecomastia, abdominal distension and ascites (shifting dullness) hepatic size, spleen Apex beat, chest sounds, added sounds/murmurs, JVP elevation, peripheral oedema Questions Other ways of assessing problematic alcohol consumption AUDIT tool - amount, frequency, patterns, waking, unable to stop, guilt, social/occupational function, blackout, interventions Most likely diagnosis for confusion Alcoholic hepatitis on b/g of chronic liver disease and hepatic encephalopathy DDx: infection, electrolyte abnormality, BSL derangements, GI haemorrhage, medications (esp sedatives), Wernicke's encephalopathy (eye signs), subdural hematoma (head trauma) Oedema differentials - nephrotic syndrome, lymphatic obstruction, alcoholic cardiomyopathy Explain the mechanisms of ascites and peripheral oedema in chronic liver disease ISBAR to handover to admitting officer You are a resident in ED when Craig arrives - the triage nurse completes another set of observations largely unchanged (mild fever, border tachycardic, confused) Primary survey no signs of respiratory compromise SpO2 92% RA BP stable BSL 5.0 Secondary survey nil acute injury old bruises of shins/forearms spider naevi jaundice, abdominal distension, hepatomegaly, oedema Further examination? PR examination - hard stool, nil evidence of bleeding Further investigations? Mechanism of the hyponatremia seen? Severe cirrhosis → fluid retention → dilutional hyponatremia Mechanism of the hypokalemia? increased circulating aldosterone, renal retention of ammonium ion in exchange for potassium, secondary renal tubular acidosis, or diuretic therapy. Management consists of giving oral potassium chloride supplements and withholding potassium-wasting diuretics. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is usually activated in patients with liver cirrhosis and this represents a homeostatic response to counterbalance the vasodilatation, arterial hypotension, and renal hypoperfusion observed in portal hypertension cirrhosis → local/systemic vasodilators → vasodilation, arterial hypotension, etc. in portal hypotension (splanchnic vasodilation) → portal hypertension → RAAS activation → excess aldosterone → K+ wasting What else can we glean from these results? Reduced hepatic synthetic function? Coags/INR, Platelets, albumin Reduced hepatic clearance? Cellular breakdown? Bilirubin Transaminitis AST:ALT > 2 → indicative of alcoholic liver disease causes of anemia in chronic liver disease bleeding, bone marrow suppression, vitamin deficiencies, red cell membrane abnormalities in chronic liver disease. list common causes of chronic liver disease viral hepatitis NASH (in association with metabolic syndrome) hemochromatosis autoimmune medication related exclude other causes of anemia B12/folate deficiency with macrocytic anemia iron deficiency direct bilirubin to distinguish between liver disease and hemolysis Investigations for chronic liver disease? Urine and blood samples are sent for culture The CXR shows cardiomegaly but no signs of interstitial oedema or infection The direct bilirubin level is elevated The urinalysis shows elevated bilirubin but no proteinuria or leucocytes - what does this set of results imply? Hepatitis serology, HbA1c, B12 and folate and iron studies are sent and results awaited Serum is also sent for autoimmune screen What should we do next? The abdominal ultrasound shows an enlarged fatty liver and mild splenomegaly. There are no focal lesions in the liver (hepatofugal) Next investigation? ascitic tap is performed The cell count shows 400 leukocytes/mm3 (90% polymorphs) and no erythrocytes are seen Raised PMNs in peritonitic fluid → SBP Albumin 12 (serum 26 [serum 30-44]) SAAH = 14 (> 11g/L) → portal hypertension Serum AAG (Ascites Albumin Gradient) 14 (<10.9) Amylase 10 (serum normal [25-125]) → excludes pancreatitis or gut perforation as a cause of peritonitis The fluid is sent for culture and cytology Most likely to return gram negative (E.coli, Klebsiella) Occasional: Strep. pneumoniae, other strep. enterococci uncommonly anaerobic bacteria Treatment for SBP → Ceftriaxone (eTG) Management of bacterial peritonitis ascites Diuretics - spironolactone (hyperaldosteronism)/aldactone fluid restriction monitor daily weights monitor kidney function (Hepatorenal syndrome) paracentesis (therapeutic, large volume ascites) hepatic encephalopathy Frequent bowel motions with lactulose rifaximin - reduce gut baterial load alcohol withdrawal Small dose benzos (loraz, oxaz > diaz) AWS ask for senior support thiamine, multivitamins MDT, SW, PT, OT Decompensated liver disease What parameters do we need to observe over the following couple of days? Is there any specific treatment/medications we need to avoid or consider carefully in Craig? Sedatives, hepatically metabolised drugs, incl opioids and paracetamol NSAIDs can cause renal failure and GIT bleeds - avoid for now How do we score severity of liver disease and what do these scores predict? Child-Pugh Score, MELD score → severity of liver disease, prognostic prediction CP - predicts likelihood o ADR to guide pharmacological therapy What other complications of chronic liver disease need to be monitored for/prevented both during the admission and on eventual discharge? Oesophageal varices → will need gastroscopy for screening Discharge summary - What main points need to be conveyed to the GP on discharge? - What key results might the GP be looking for in the summary? - How soon will Craig need to see the GP and what needs to be considered at that first follow up appointment?

docs.text: Malignant ascites case Important topics to review Ascites Malignancies associated with ascites Familial cancer syndromes Case presentation Background Robyn is a 42 year old mother of three teenage children who presents to her GP in Kempsey complaining of increased abdominal distension and weight loss, together with increasing exertional dyspnoea Presenting complaint Increased abdominal distension, weight loss increased exertional dyspnoea She has not been to the GP in the past few years for acute illness but has had pap smears regularly (no abnormality detected) Associated regular periods on OCP BP normal on previous visits Systems review NAD - post-meal bloating and mild fatigue nil changes in bowel habits or pain Questions What are some causes for unintentional weight loss? GI causes (ulcer, coeliac, colitis) Cancer Endocrine (thyroid, DM, adrenal) Psychological/psychiatric (e.g. depression) Other systemic diseases (heart failure, chronic liver diseases, renal disease, autoimmune diseases, chronic infections) malnutrition appetite suppression Medications history On OCP otherwise nil regular meds FHx Nil Hx bowel cancer, not on bowel cancer screening breast cancer in mother and elder sister - both alive Questions Is the family history of cancer relevant? https://www.bci.org.au/breast-cancer-information/fact-sheets/family-history-breast-cancer/ Social history Stay at home mum moderate physical activity - tennis, walking Mother to teenagers Ex-smoker (20PYHx), nil alcohol consumption Examination Nil jaundice, rahes Alert, oriented x3 Vitals NAD, afebrile Weight 54kg (previously 62kg 12 months ago) Moderate distension of abdomen, non-tender shifting dullness, nil organomegaly or lymphadenopathy dullness and decreased AE on R) base extending to 1/3rd of chest posteriorly - otherwise chest clear to auscultation nil peripheral oedema or leg swelling/tenderness or abnormal signs on CVD exam Questions Other examinations? Ascites + significant weight loss → examine for common malignances Breast exam NAD PR and PV NAD Urinalysis - to exclude hematuria Investigations UA normal Questions Should we do tumour markers? Not diagnostic on their own - can SUPPORT a highly suspicious diagnosis, or for tracking Iron studies? Useful to assess anemia Issues with less targeted approach for investigation? Overdiagnosis Further management/investigations CT AP Pleural tap Further questions/discussion What are the potential mechanisms of malignant ascites? What are the commonest malignancies associated with this? Ongoing management Robyn comes back to see you to discuss her investigation results. She is already aware you are pretty concerned after you let her know that there were some abnormal findings on her chest xray and organised the CT. How are you going to convey the investigation findings to Robyn? You will need to discuss the need for an oncology referral to discuss potential treatment options What important information will you convey in your referral letter to the oncologist?

docs.text: Stroke and TIA Cerebrovascular disease Stroke syndromes Presentation Maria is a 76 year old lady of Italian descent. She has been in Australia for 40 years and speaks English well. She previously worked as a teacher’s aide in the local primary school. Maria lives with her son Joe and his wife in Wyoming and is usually independent with all her activities of daily living although Joe helps out with some more complicated financial transactions and has done so since his Dad passed away ten years ago. Maria’s family bring her to the emergency department at Gosford Hospital as they were concerned to find that whilst having her morning cup of tea (around 8am) she appeared to develop some mild right facial weakness and they were having difficulty understanding what she was trying to say. She picked up her mug and promptly dropped it. Maria’s family bring her to the emergency department at Gosford Hospital as they were concerned to find that whilst having her morning cup of tea (around 8am) she appeared to develop some mild right facial weakness and they were having difficulty understanding what she was trying to say. She picked up her mug and promptly dropped it. She was able to walk to the car so they brought her to the hospital ED themselves as they were only 5 minutes drive away. Questions (Part 1): Was it a smart idea to bring Maria into hospital by family car? What are the advantages of calling an ambulance? Manage deterioration Appropriate hospital BAT CALL - to call ahead so no delay on arrival How should she be triaged on arrival, what are the critical components of initial assessment? ABCDE Level of consciousness Airway security History When you ask they state that Maria seemed perfectly fine when she went to bed the night before and on first waking this morning. Chest XR Interpretation Weber Liu Basic concepts We only see differences in density outline of mediastinum visible due to aerated lung next to it white branching pulmonary vessels visible due to air in alveolar spaces next to vessels blood vessels behind the liver in R) LL due to vessels outlined by air loss of vessels = ?lesion Consolidation Can be blood, fluid, pus or protein hard to tell what it is, needs clinical correlation Look through the heart and diaphragm to look for consolidation AP CXR The very basics Confirm ID Patient name, age / DOB, sex Type of film – PA or AP, erect or supine, correct L/R marker, inspiratory/expiratory series Date and time of study RIPE R otation – medial clavicle ends equidistant from spinous process I nspiration – 5-6 anterior ribs in MCL or 8-10 posterior ribs above diaphragm, poor inspiration?, hyperexpanded? P icture – straight vs oblique, entire lung fields, scapulae outside lung fields, angulation (ie ’tilt’ in vertical plane) E xposure (Penetration) – IV disc spaces, spinous processes to ~T4, L) hemidiaphragm visible through cardiac shadow. Airway Trachea – central or slightly to right lung as crosses aortic arch Paratracheal/mediastinal masses or adenopathy Carina & RMB/LMB Right middle lobe (R) hugs the right heart border Lingula (L) touches L) heart border L) lower lobe touches the descending aorta - loss of descending thoracic aorta indicates consolidation of L) LL touches the L) hemidiaphragm Bones Ribs, sternum, spine, clavicles – symmetry, fractures, dislocations, lytic lesions, density Soft tissues – looking for symmetry, swelling, loss of tissue planes, subcutaneous air, masses Breast shadows Calcification – great vessels, carotids Cardiomediastinum Mediastinal width <8cm on PA film Aortic knob Hilum – T6-7 IV disc level, left hilum is usually higher (2cm) and squarer than the V-shaped right hilum. Check vessels, calcification. Heart position –⅔ to left, ⅓ to right Heart size – measure cardiothoracic ratio on PA film (normal <0.5) Heart borders – R) border is R) atrium, L) border is L) ventricle & atrium Heart shape Aortic stripe Diaphragm Hemidiaphragm levels – Right Lung higher than Left Lung (~2.5cm / 1 intercostal space) Diaphragm shape/contour Cardiophrenic and costophrenic angles – clear and sharp Gastric bubble / colonic air Subdiaphragmatic air (pneumoperitoneum) Extras ETT, CVP line, NG tube, PA catheters ECG electrodes, PICC line, chest tube PPM, AIDC, metalwork Fields Lung Fields: Vascularity – to ~2cm of pleural surface (~3cm in apices), vessels in bases > apices Pneumothorax – don’t forget apices Lung field outlines – abnormal opacity/lucency, atelectasis, collapse, consolidation, bullae Horizontal fissure on Right Lung Pulmonary infiltrates – interstitial vs alveolar pattern Coin lesions Cavitary lesions Pleura Pleural reflections Pleural thickening -- -- -- - Often posterior -- -- -- - Posterior structure -- -- - border superior to heart -- - forms right heart border -- - sits on bottom of diaphragm -- - RV on AP film, extends into pulmoanry artery -- -- - bulges further out on LA dilatation -- - LV forming left heart border -- -- - extends beyond SVC -- - below heart -- - seen behind L) clavicle Additional points of reference - should be of equal transradiancy - horizontal fissure may be more difficult - should be around hilum to 6th rib in axillary line - displacement could indicate lung collapse - L) hilum should be higher than R) - diff should be < 2.5cm - should be concave and appear similar -- - check for sharp and clear -- - Note R) diaphragm should be higher than L) diaphragm - difference should be < 3cm - outline should be smooth -- - white edge should be < 2-3cm wide on erect film - central but deviates slightly right at aortic knuckle - shifting could indicate mediastinum or lung issue -- - Cardiac size should be < half the diameter of the chest - fuzziness of the mediastinum should only ever been seen at the intersection of the heart and diaphragm -- Lateral film Normal 'more black' sign vertebral bodies become more radiotransparent as you move down Double diaphragm Can see two diaphragms on lateral if you can only see 1, consider some form of consolidation sitting over a lung More black sign Normal finding in lateral CXR gradual increase in apparent radiolucency of vertebral bodies from upper to lower chest due to increased proportion of chest comprosed of air containing lungs over distal dorsal spine c.f. upper parts on displacement of air by higher attentuation material (e.g. consolidation, fluid, mass), lower thoracic vertebral bodies become more radiodense (i.e. loss of the more black sign ) https://radiopaedia.org/articles/more-black-sign - oblique fissure - blue area = if lung were to collapse, where you would see opacity -- identify diaphragms R) hemi - stretches across whole thorax and can be clearly seen passing through heart border L) hemi disappears at posterior border of heart pleural effusion can result in blunding of costophrenic angle (anteriorly or posteriorly) lung fields in front and above heart vs. behind heart - expect equal density look for lesions retrosternal space should be blackest part of film anterior mediastinal mass will turn this space white horizontal fissure faint white line passing horizontally from mid-hilum to anterior chest wall - if not horizontal, the fissure is displaced oblique fissure T4/5 through hilum, ending anterior 1/3rd of diaphragm Hilar density dense hilum can indicate mass vertebral bodies should get darker lower vertebral collapse or density changes - can indicate bone disease

Chest XR cases 1 Weber Liu Case 21M with severe Mitral regurgitation and chest pain and known seizure disorder. Presented to ED with seizures. -- Impression - L) shoulder dislocation - R) lower rib fracture - aspiration pneumonia Case 42M healthy gentleman presenting with few days hx of fever and cough -- A B C D - flat, hyperinflated E F - dense consolidation in right middle lobe Imp: R) middle lobe pneumonia Case 64M otherwise healthy with cough and chest pain -- A B C D E F - Right lower lobe pneumonia (loss of some hemidiaphragm, however R) heart border still visible - Impression: R)LL pneumonia Zooming in ... -- Air bronchogram (air filled bronchi surrounded by purulent alveoli) - support pneumonia diagnosis Case 65F with acute sharp pleuritic chest pain, fairly health with obesity, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia. Dyspnoeic, tachycardiac, SpO2 90%, nil prior pulmonary history -- Lateral scan -- - could trace out left hemidiaphragm 1 year ago - could see increased lucency as you trace spine 1 year ago (the spine sign) - indication of consolidated lung imp: retrocardiac pneumonia, confirmed on CT chest Case 45F 2 week hx of cough and low grade fever. Hypoxic and tachypnoeic. Lung sounds crackly -- - increased interstitial markings, nil obvious pneumonia - diffuse interstitial markings imp: atypical pnuemonia diagnosis: AIDS with PCP Case -- - patchy white hilar region on R) -- - Diagnosis - PCP pnuemonia - DDx - infective endocarditis - metastasis Case 72F with severe onset SOB. -- - cardiomegaly - increased interstitial markings - cephalisation Imp: Pulmonary oedema -- - vessels should be smaller at the top due to gravity - if upper lobe vessels appear similar in diameter to lower lobe, this is a reflection of increased back pressure (reduced venous return) - thickened fissure can be seen - indication of oedema - perihilar fullness/fluffiness - hazy - everything becomes more indistinct -- - Kerley B lines - engorged interlobular septa commonly seen with pulmonary oedema -- Incomplete aortic ring at aortic arch calcification but not continuous most specific CXR finding for aortic dissection -- 70F had an aortic dissection, developed an aortic flap which reached aortic root, resulting in her pulmonary oedema Case M sudden onset respiratory distress -- - A - endotracheal tube in situ - B - C - enlarged heart - D - E - pacer pads, defibrillator pads - F - perihilar consolidation, cephalisation, engorged fissure, kerley B lines at base Imp: Pulmonary oedema Case 45M smoker with sharp pleuritic chest and back pain -- A - hyperinflated -- pleural reflection in a pneumothorax Case 2AM on Saturday, 35M presents with sudden onset chest pain, pleuritic and dyspnoeic -- Lateral view -- A B C - extra lines and lucencies seen (pleural reflections lifted off heart) D E F Imp: Pneumomediastinum References https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p3NCQaGFQ-g&ab_channel=TheCenterforMedicalEducation

He has been underweight since childhood. Details Name - NA AP/PA/Lateral - NA Date of study - NA Basics Rotation - good rotation Inspiration - good inspiration, 10th posterior rib at MCL Picture - good Exposure - good exposure, spinous processes visible A-F approach Airways - trachea midline, deviated R) near aortic knuckle. R) deviation of carina and main bronchi. upper bronchial wall thickening with ring shadows and patches of consolidation Bones - no obvious fractures noted. increased adiposity. acromioclavicular joints and rotator cuffs not appropriately visible for comment. Cardiomediastinum - cardiac borders fuzzy on either side. patchy opacification of hilum in both lung fields. Diaphragm - scalloping appearance of diaphragm. flattened. R higher than L diaphragm as expected. costophrenic angles clear, cardiophrenic angles fuzzy. flattened, features if mild airflow obstruction Extras - nil attachments. Fields - hazy opacification across both lung fields. -- - hazy opacification posterior to heart and increased radiolucency in posterior lung fields - ring shadows and clear upper lobe predominance of bronchiectasis Finding Cystic bronchiectasis LITFL Case 2 44 yo man has routine CXR after possible faint Details Name - NA AP/PA/Lateral - NA Date of study - NA Basics Rotation - rotation appropriate, perhaps mildly rotated to L Inspiration - appropriate, anterior rib 6 at MCL Picture - Good Exposure - appropriate, can see spinous processes at T4 A-F approach Airways - trachea midline with mild L) sided angulation. carina and main bronchi midline and acceptable Bones - nil obvious fractures or soft tissue injury. large body habitus. Cardiomediastinum - clear cardiac burder with heart on R) (?dextrocardia). cardiac size normal. Aortic knuckle R) sided. Diaphragm - acceptable. cardiophrenic angles and costophrenic angles visible. Gastric bubble right sided Extras - NAD Fields - fissures vieible but not pronounced. nil obvious cephalisation or vessels or kerley B lines. hilar opacifties similarly positioned and equal density bilaterally. coarse thickened bronchial markings and small ring shadows notably in upper lobes consistent with bronchiectasis Findings Dextrocardia right sided stomach bubble may suggest situs inversus Kartagener syndrome - primary ciliary dyskinesia LITFL Case 3 55 yo lady presents with worsening chronic cough and wheeze References https://litfl.com/top-100/cxr/
